The List 2023

Dec 23, 2023

At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

Intro.

Iâ€™ve been making these lists for more than two decades now, but each time November rolls around and itâ€™s time to start chiseling down the mountain of a yearâ€™s releases into a set of twenty, I find myself falling into the same mental trap. Iâ€™ve become better at it over time, but I still find that I have to make the conscious effort to remind myself: Iâ€™m not trying to make a list of the objectively â€˜bestâ€™ albums of 2023 â€”Â there are plenty of magazines and websites out there pretending thatâ€™s possible. My task is to produce a run-down of the twenty records that have brought me the most joy.

When I remember to think about things that way, the task of constructing the list becomes a little easier. Itâ€™s not a question of whether I think album Y is better than album Z: itâ€™s about which made me smile more, hum more, sing more, dance more. So, here they are, the twenty album-length records, released in 2023, which moved me the most.

20. Jadu Heart â€”Â Derealised

Thereâ€™s a lot going on in Jadu Heartâ€™s sound. So much so, that early in my time with it, I had Derealised pigeonholed first as a post-shoegaze record, then as a dream-pop record, before (de)realising that it didnâ€™t really matter which of their influences are strongest on any given track â€”Â their sound is their own. What the record has throughout, is a strong sense of core melodies, and a production style that layers hazy tones into the mix to arresting effect. â€˜Cocoonâ€™ is a straight-ahead, low-key pop song, where â€˜I Shimmerâ€™ is messier (and more clearly in debt to mbv). Never rushed â€”Â even at their most attention-demanding (eg. the Strokes-on-benzos push and pull of the aptly-titled â€˜Swayâ€™) these are songs that wash over the listener easily, casting their spell subtly. Album highlight â€˜Freedomâ€™ is perhaps the sound at its tightest, but even here itâ€™s fuzzy at the edges, and loose in the weave. After the briefest of tours through some of their previous work, it seems this is an outfit still evolving, not content to settle into one sound. However, the songwriting (and mood-setting) here is of a quality that will keep me tuned in to see whatâ€™s next.

19. Metallica â€”Â 72 Seasons

I vividly recall the giddy feeling induced by the arrival of Death Magnetic in 2008: Metallica had finally released another album I truly liked, from start-to-finish, a full 17 years on from having last done so with their 1991 self-titled masterpiece. Subsequently, a less-than-impressive Lou Reed collaboration in 2011 left me cold, as did (the fairly well-received) Hardwiredâ€¦ to Self-Destruct (2016). Which meant, upon the arrival of 72 Seasons in April, there was a heavy measure of relief in the mix for me, when the first listen confirmed what Iâ€™d dared not count on after three strong pre-released tracks: it was good! Like, really, properly good.

Eight months on, the bigger surprise is how relatively low the album has placed. There were a few weeks when I was playing the heck out of it, thrilled by its energy (highlight, and career top 30 contender â€˜Lux Ã†ternaâ€™) and ambition (11-minute final track â€˜Inamorataâ€™). Over time the fire dimmed a little, and Iâ€™ve only made the trip through the full 77 minutes a few times in the latter half of the year. When I have, however, thereâ€™s still not a weak track to be found, and even if the front half feels stronger, latter highlights â€˜Too For Gone?â€™ and the aforementioned epic closer, are not to be missed.

72 Seasons is, by some measure, the â€˜heaviestâ€™ record on this list, and Iâ€™m not blind to the fact that nostalgia is playing its part here. Iâ€™m confident there were any number of â€˜betterâ€™ metal records released in 2023, but Iâ€™m happy just to have the company of Lars and the boys once more. Even if you can only count on one great Metallica album every decade-and-a-half, it was a joy to have this one.

18. Sebastian Rochford & Kit Downes â€”Â A Short Diary

This is a set of delicate compositions for piano and drums, from previous Mercury nominee Kit Downes, and Sons of Kemet member / Polar Bear band-leader Seb Rochford (whom Iâ€™ve kept an eye on since Peepers (2010)). On reflection, it feels as though I listened to less jazz in 2023 than has been the case in recent years â€”Â the reason, if there is one, eludes me â€”Â but there were a small number of records I really enjoyed. This relatively brief collection of sparse, reflective pieces has not only lasted since I first played it in January, it has grown in my mind as Iâ€™ve found myself returning to it. Over that time Iâ€™ve found my enjoyment increasing alongside my ability to anticipate the melodiesâ€™ next step and turn. Iâ€™ve read comparisons to Bach and Mahler, the aptness of which lies beyond my ken. I do know that the interplay between the two instruments creates a kind of magic for me, as they find new and surprising ways to complement one another.

A hat tip is owed to Tyshawn Sorey, whose Continuing narrowly misses out on a place here. That record was eagerly anticipated by me, following his appearance in the top 10 of my 2021 list. It dropped mid-year, and Iâ€™ve spent far too little time with it up to this point.

17. Screaming Females â€”Â Desire Pathway

As I write this, the news of Screaming Females breaking up is less than a week old. Iâ€™d arrived late to the band, thrilled by 2018â€™s All At Once, which placed 14th for me that year. Five years on, its no surprise that I was eager to receive another set of super-melodic, fuzzed up, alt rock treats, all carried along by Marissa Paternosterâ€™s sidewinding guitar and singular vocals.

More than capable of operating across a few different gears â€”Â from the call to arms of opener â€˜Brass Bellâ€™ to the poppy jaunt of â€˜Mourning Doveâ€™, via arms-around-shoulders sing-along â€˜Beyond the Voidâ€™ â€”Â the unifying element here is a well-honed ear for hooks, and a mastery of classic guitar / drums / bass dynamics. Each element enjoys its time to shine, but the delight is in how seamlessly it all fits together to make a sound that feels both familiar, and always welcome.

In their disbandment announcement, they are rightly proud of the approach theyâ€™ve taken over the last 18 years:

We funded and made the records we wanted to make. We did our own art. We printed a lot of our own merch. We managed ourselves. Probably most importantly we loaded up our van with our gear and traveled around the world to play shows wherever you would have us.

Everything about Screaming Females speaks of people who have music in their blood. I, for one, hope and expect to hear Paternosterâ€™s voice again.

16. Unknown Mortal Orchestra â€”Â V

By the time I started paying attention to Spoon, with 2014â€™s They Want My Soul, theyâ€™d put out eight records over the course of almost two full decades. When I fell head-over-heels for Lowâ€™s Double Negative in 2018, theyâ€™d already put in a shift of 24 years and a dozen LPs. All of which is to say that, discovering Unknown Mortal Orchestra on their fifth (arguably sixth?) album, may be illustrative of profound ignorance on my part, but itâ€™s not my worst offence.

V proved to be a lot to digest at once. Whilst by no means overly long, the mood it conjures is such that the record plays for me like a 40 minute orchestral movement. Itâ€™s alternative music in a different, perhaps truer, sense: pop that has been shifted somehow into a weirder, more cerebral mode. For me V echoed some of the work of previous list grandee Toro y Moi. The production here is similarly gauzy, and the vocal delivery is akin to Chaz Bearâ€™s languid style. This is easy-sounding music, which I fall easily into letting wash over me, though Iâ€™ve learned that closer attention pays dividends. Iâ€™m still not sure Iâ€™ve entirely grasped everything thatâ€™s going on here, but itâ€™s a record that keeps compelling me back to dive deeper.

15. K-Lone â€”Â Swells

K-Loneâ€™s debut, Cape Cira, didnâ€™t quite make my list in 2020, but it was in close contention right up until the end. (If I could put myself back into that mental space, Iâ€™d perhaps discover that its power had been diluted by the presence of work that year by Caribou, Georgia, and Four Tet, but who knows?) Here on album number two, the Brighton-based producer has really captured something special: unequal parts dub, synth-pop, and the â€˜minimalâ€™ end of house to which Iâ€™m so partial.

The opening of â€˜Sawsâ€™ is misleading, its discordant vocal sample suggesting we might be in for something more disjointed and more difficult. Itâ€™s quickly subsumed in a warm bath of synth chords, with playful notes dancing atop. Perhaps this is intended to accustom the listener to keep their wits about them. The instrumentation remains fairly consistent throughout, with a particularly distinct percussion palette that underpins the whole ride, but thatâ€™s not to say the record doesnâ€™t go places. These ten tracks seem to grow and bloom in front of the listener, each moment-to-moment twist a delight to behold. Playing with mournful reversed (?) string samples on â€˜Stringsâ€™; adding a more prominent vocal on â€˜With Uâ€™; reaching a dubby zenith on â€˜Love Isâ€™â€¦ the 46 minutes embrace a lot of different dynamics, and meld them into something captivating.

14. Puma Blue â€” Holy Waters

The overall sonic profile of Puma Blue is unlike anything else I encountered this year. Jacob Allenâ€™s other release of 2023 is a sparse, delicate rendition of Nina Simoneâ€™s â€˜Twelfth of Neverâ€™, which is indicative of a fundamental element of his sound. Itâ€™s augmented on Holy Waters by a blend of trip hop-adjacent percussion, haunting synths, and other precisely arranged additions. Allenâ€™s sultry, rich vocal always remains central, and whether heâ€™s pining for an absent love (â€˜Houndsâ€™) or ruminating on attachment (title track â€˜Holy Watersâ€™), it feels as though the instrumentation has been constructed â€” and given a spacious, dusky mix â€” so as best to support his poetic lyricism, and his delicate delivery. No small part of my enjoyment is owed to the fact that listening to Holy Waters feels as close as we can get to new material from the late Jeff Buckley.

There are also frequent jazz touches (eg. when the drums and bass get a little Hail to the Thief, on â€˜Too Much, Too Muchâ€™), which only contribute further to a singular-sounding record that I found myself returning to repeatedly, ideally on headphones, after the sun had set.

13. Bully â€”Â Lucky For You

When writing last year’s list, I noted the frequency with which artists were incorporating some flavour of shoegaze / dream-pop tone into their work. It’s a trend that I’ve noticed continuing this year, and nowhere more clearly than on Lucky for You. In the mix here are grungy guitar effects, fuzzed-up bass, and a vocal delivery that calls to my mind Sheryl / Alanis at their most forthright.

A few records this year fit roughly into this same category. I really enjoyed work by Claud (dreamier?), Blondshell, PONY (poppier?), and Sir Chloe â€“ all were in shortlist contention; the latter could easily have been on the final list. What sets Bully apart for me is the consistently excellent songwriting, and the variety of ways Alicia Bognanno finds to play with the colours on her palate. The driving, bouncing ‘Days Move Slow’, followed by the more contemplative ‘A Wonderful Life’ is but one of several mode shifts that land like marvellous one-two punches. To my mind, the record’s strongest song (amongst many contenders) is the earnest ‘How Will I Know’, with its heartfelt plea of a chorus. It’s unlikely to have been at all intentional, but it quickly became entangled in my mind with Olivier Assayas’s movie Personal Shopper (2016), which I love beyond reason.

12. Illiterate Light â€”Â Sunburned

Hereâ€™s a record I discovered quite early on in the year, and which was one of the first 2023 releases to make an impression. Illiterate Lightâ€™s sound reminded me a little of the likes of Screaming Trees: attuned perfectly to a particular wavelength of alt-rock, cut with Americana. The production on Sunburned also employs some tricks (such as applying the faintest echo to Jeff Gormanâ€™s vocal) that result in the record sounding expansive and encompassing. It was only after a fair few listens that I discovered that Illiterate Light is only a two-piece! Shortly thereafter, I watched some live performance videos, bewitched by Jake Cochranâ€™s use of a standing drum kit; stunned by Gorman playing synth with his feet, whilst also handling vocal and guitar duties.

Itâ€™s tempting to attribute the albumâ€™s tight execution, and very definite sense of a sound, to it being the product of only two people working in harmony. Whether or not thatâ€™s true, the result is a set of richly melodic compositions, shot through with an emotional weariness that occasionally gives way to moments of cathartic brightness. â€˜Wake Up Nowâ€™ is a bombastic start, uncharacteristic in its general positivity; it presages stories of loss, relationship struggle, and paranoia, all expertly rendered, if a little gloomy. For my money, things go a little too far on the albumâ€™s only weak moment: penultimate track â€˜Fuck LAâ€™, which feels too slight and half-hearted, particularly compared to the colossal â€˜Light Me Upâ€™, or the personal-feeling â€˜Hellraiserâ€™.

NB. later in the year, the band released a four-track EP which is also great, but which plays with some much brighter moods on the tracks not titled â€˜Cheap Divorceâ€™.

11. Chris Farren â€”Â Doom Singer

The loudest, sweatiest, most raucous gig I attended in 2023 was to watch Chris Farren (and, new addition to the touring outfit, drummer Frankie) tear apart a tiny room upstairs in an Oxford pub. The tour was in support of his fifth solo album, but heâ€™s also a veteran of other outfits: Fake Problems, and Antarctigo Vespucci. Iâ€™m somewhat ashamed to say that I had no familiarity with any of those earlier records when I hit play on Doom Singer back in August. Since then itâ€™s been in consistent rotation, its mix of poppy hooks, grungy riffs, and tongue-in-cheek lyrics an absolute delight from explosive start (â€˜Bluishâ€™) to melancholy finish (â€˜Statue Songâ€™). Farrenâ€™s sound captures all the melodicism I love in bands like Jimmy Eat World, and transmutes their earnestness with a playful sense of humour, without undercutting the emotional weight. Each three-minute dose of wit and verve is a delight to sing along to, with a wry smile on your face. Album highlight â€˜Cosmic Leashâ€™ stretches both the emotive and sonic range a little further, to wonderful effect.

Iâ€™ve dipped into more of Farrenâ€™s output since Doom Singer grabbed my attention, and itâ€™s clear thereâ€™s a lot more where this came from. Iâ€™ll certainly be paying attention from now on.

10. Olivia Dean â€”Â Messy

I think I first encountered Olivia Deanâ€™s name amongst the nominees for this yearâ€™s Mercury Prize. By the time the award show itself rolled around, I would have given the statuette to her (even over Jockstrapâ€™s I Love You Jennifer B, which I still rue leaving off last yearâ€™s list). Messy â€” inaptly titled by a perfectionist â€”Â is a record that feels so well put together, and of such consistent quality, that a few months into my relationship with it, I started to find it difficult to believe I hadnâ€™t known some of these songs (the playful big band flirtation â€˜Diveâ€™; the sultry â€˜The Ladies Roomâ€™) for years. And, the list continues: the immaculately polished R&B of â€˜The Hardest Partâ€™; the sweet, coy poetry of â€˜I Could Be a Floristâ€™; the delightful family history of closer â€˜Carmenâ€™ â€“Â each showcases a talent for affecting lyricism, and a singer fully in command of their instrument: a little Lauren Hill, and a little Amy Winehouse.

Last year this same niche was filled for me by Amber Markâ€™s excellent Three Dimensions Deep, and whilst I donâ€™t find that I chime with a great deal of modern, mainstream R&B / soul, I deeply appreciate having had these records over the last couple of years, as a refuge of uncomplicated comfort. Messy has a warm and inviting aura that I reached for on several occasions, out of a desire simply to be close to that quality.

9. Andrea â€” Due in Color

Mononymous Italian producer Andrea has been putting out work on the Zenker brothersâ€™ label Ilian Tape for a decade, and whilst the name has crossed my awareness over the years, debut album Ritorno (2020) isnâ€™t one that I remember playing. My first encounter with Due In Colour, however, came with a strong recommendation, and it does not disappoint. A melange of muted club beats, jazz-adjacent percussion, and washed out production, makes every minute of this recordâ€™s hour-plus runtime a mesmerising journey. Each composition flows one into the next, as the hazy instrumentation is carried through a range of tempos, from lounge chair to dance floor.

I feel like I go looking for an album roughly in this space each year, and since I was tipped to Due in Color back in March, it has remained a go-to record for me whenever Iâ€™ve been in the mood. Only time will tell whether it wears as well for me as the very best examples of its kind, such as Shigetoâ€™s No Better Time Than Now (17th in 2013), which I still play regularly.

8. Buck 65 â€”Â Super Dope

I almost donâ€™t need to write this entry. The one and only Legendary Buck 65 took second place on last yearâ€™s list, with his first album in seven years. As though surprising himself that he still had all this in him, heâ€™s followed up in 2023 with not one, or two, but three records. One, a collaborative effort with Doseone and Jel, 25 years in the making. The other two, essentially straight-up sequels to last yearâ€™s King of Drums. Both Mayâ€™s Super Dope and Novemberâ€™s Punk Rock B-Boy are cut from the same cloth as 2022â€™s glorious reemergence: immaculately constructed beats, and rhymes as clever and convoluted as they are goofily self-aware. Add in frequent, increasingly niche baseball shout outs, and it sometimes feels like these records are being made especially for me.

Iâ€™m listing Super Dope here because, at this point, I know it better. My suspicion is that, when I find more time to spend with the newer record, Iâ€™ll enjoy it just as much. These are albums with a lot to unpack, and itâ€™s been my experience that they only grow on me over time. The same is true of my favourite of Buckâ€™s 90s & 00s output, but â€”Â if asked to choose â€”Â I might say weâ€™re currently in his best era. Iâ€™ll take as many of these as he wants to put out.

7. Cut Worms â€” Cut Worms

This self-titled release is Max Clarkeâ€™s third album as Cut Worms, and was a revelation to me when I happened upon it this summer. Despite sounding like a blend of Bright Eyes-esque folk, classic 60s rock nâ€™ roll, and a strong dose of Americana, everything about this felt fresh and vital to me the first time I heard it, and 34 minutes later I found myself playing it again. The recordâ€™s balance of easygoing melody, simple constructions, and personal lyrics shot through with melancholy, feels earnest and honest, despite the soundâ€™s affectations. Itâ€™s an album that invites you to share in the warmth of its lo-fi production, and to tap your foot to its relaxed pace. Each three minute track has the feel of having been discovered on some long-lost 7-inch, and polished to glowing life.

Thereâ€™s something enormously endearing about both the world that Clarkeâ€™s songs conjure, and the way in which heâ€™s delivering it. Though musically very different, itâ€™s a spell that has similar effect to those early White Stripes records that I fell for two decades ago.

When it comes to sequencing this list each year, thereâ€™s usually a clear demarcating line between the very tip top, cream of the cream records, and a larger group that are all great, and deserving of a place, but which donâ€™t shine quite so scorchingly bright. I loved my time with all fourteen records listed thus far, but the margins are thin between them, and between a dozen more records just over the horizon of a top 20. For me, there were half a dozen albums this year that were truly a cut above, and which I anticipate playing for years to come. Welcome to the top six.

6. boygenius â€” the record

Phoebe Bridgers' Punisher placed 17th on my 2020 list, and has had more staying power than at least five of the records that ranked above it. Lucy Dacus’s Historian was in contention for a spot in 2018, and I’ve enjoyed her solo output since. I also enjoyed Julien Baker’s 2021 LP Little Oblivions, but of the trio that comprise boygenius, she was perhaps the least well known to me. It quickly became clear on a couple of listens, however, that boygenius is a true gestalt: the sum greater than the parts.

Opening a capella number â€˜Without You Without Themâ€™ might not be to everyoneâ€™s taste, but itâ€™s certainly an effective showcase of how well the three voices harmonise. And such is the joy of the record: the lyrics (hip, knowing, sometimes resigned, often open-hearted), and the simple, spacious compositions, are certainly full of charm, but its the melding of three different voices and sensibilities into a magical whole, which truly magnetises. Fragility and strength ebb and flow throughout the album, both in terms of message and delivery. The (post-a capella) introductory trilogy of â€˜$20â€™, â€˜Emily Iâ€™m Sorryâ€™, & â€˜True Blueâ€™ (complete with interlinked videos (directed by Kristen Stewart)) is a microcosm of the set as a whole. As the three voices take it in turns supporting one another in telling personal stories in verse, you get the distinct feeling that this is a folk record in disguise. Even at its rockiest (â€˜Satanistâ€™) its defining characteristic is raw emotionality.Â As heart-swollen and touching as anything from the era of peak Saddle Creek, these were songs I returned to countless times since the LPâ€™s arrival in March, basking in increased familiarity.

5. Priya Ragu â€” Santhosam

Priya was one of the most welcome surprises of 2021, taking third place on my list that year with her debut LP damnshestamil. There are cuts on there so well-honed and perfectly polished (‘Leaf High’, ‘Good Love 2.0’, & ‘Chicken Lemon Rice’ amongst them) that I’ll admit to a soupÃ§on of doubt that another record would yield comparable results. There have been plenty of artists over the years, who have thrilled with their first offering, and then proven incapable of following up. Perhaps unfairly, the first to mind is La Roux:Â an exemplary debut in 2009, the quality of which hasn’t been close to matched by anything on the subsequent two albums in the 14 years since.

Well, no such problem for Priya Ragu, who has filled Santhosam with fine examples of her unique blend of soul / hip-hop / R&B and influences from her Sri Lankan-Tamil / Swiss upbringing. I still hear a little Janet (Miss Jackson if you’re nasty) in the ease with which Priya does it, but truly this sound is entirely its own thing. Its infectious warmth and colour characterises track-after-track of immaculately danceable, smile-along pop. Even when tackling more difficult subject matter â€”Â such as racist policing on ‘Black Goose’ â€” there’s an undertone of communal understanding and unity. If proof were needed that Ragu is the real thing, it’s in no short supply here. I’m still listening to the debut with some regularity, and I also anticipate playing this for years to come.

4. Paramore â€” This Is Why

Of Paramoreâ€™s previous output, Brand New Eyes is the previous high-water mark: 8th in 2009. Their self-titled record reached 12th in 2013, and After Laughter hit 10th in 2017. Obviously all of that is contextual, which perhaps explains why â€”Â ranked against one another â€”Â they would fall in an order other than that suggested by their relative competitiveness in their respective end-of-year running. We should also note front woman Hayley Williamsâ€™s solo work: Petals for Armour broke the top five on my 2020 list, before follow-up Flowers for Vases / Descansos failed to place the following year. All of this makes a kind of sense, if you can hold it all in your head at the same time. The folkier, sparser arrangements of the latter solo record didnâ€™t work for me in the same way that the combination of Williamsâ€™s voice, artful lyric, and ear for a pop-rock hook have across other contexts. Whatâ€™s more, at the close of 2023, I count myself as probably more of a Paramore fan than I have been at any point in the past. Looping This Is Why for weeks after its February release predictably led to some level of burnout. That led, in turn, to a revisiting of their previous work, which â€”Â despite the fact that I already knew it well â€”Â deepened my admiration for their dynamic, ambitious brand of pop-punk-dance-rock.

This Is Why stands as perhaps the apotheosis of their style. Itâ€™s Paramoreâ€™s best record, and a showcase to the most mature version of their sound. The opener and title track is all groovy bass and slinky vocal, at least until its chant of a chorus; â€˜The Newsâ€™ is more jagged and motivated; â€˜Running Out of Timeâ€™ is more narrowly focussed, but no less enthused. My personal favourite, since my early days with the album, has been â€˜You Firstâ€™, a synth-infused run up and down the gears that wouldnâ€™t sound out of place on a Metric release.

The six years between releases â€” and Williamsâ€™ solo output â€”Â had me questioning whether Paramore were in fact on some kind of unannounced / unofficial hiatus. Itâ€™s been a pleasure to revel not only in their return, but in their having reached new heights.

3. Romy â€” Mid Air

When, at the very beginning of opener ‘Loveher’, Romy Madley Croft softly intones a request to “turn it up a bit more”, I almost invariably comply. Mid Air is an album I want to be surrounded by and enveloped in, and a little additional volume helps cast the spell. Another vital ingredient is Croft’s soft, sweet vocal, of which I’ve always been a fan: The xx’s Coexist placed 20th in 2012; I See You, 16th in 2017. Add in lyrics that tell personal and true-feeling stories about queer love and mental health, all suffused with a pleasing optimism. And on top of that, there’s the production, which takes Fred Again..’s (sic) intimate, soft-touch style and (for this listener) elevates it into a poppier mode.

From ‘Loveher’ through to closer ‘She’s On My Mind’, Mid Air quickly felt very much as though it had been conceived as an album, as opposed to discrete songs. Both the mood, and the unfolding romantic narrative feel like a single journey, though one with identifiable landmarks. ‘The Sea’ is coy and meandering; ‘Strong’ is the big beat peak; ‘Did I’ dims the lights; late album highlight ‘Enjoy Your Life’ is an unimpeachable dance anthem.

With this release, Romy eclipses her xx band mate Jamie xx’s 8th place on my 2015 list, for his solo debut In Colour. At this point, I’m impatiently awaiting another xx LP, and also more solo work from â€“ with apologies to Oliver Sim, whose own solo record, Hideous Bastard, didn’t entirely work for me last year â€“ two of its members. If I could only have one though, at this point I’d choose Romy in a heartbeat. No record felt more like an embrace this year than Mid Air.

2. Metric â€” Formentera II

When it comes to record releases, itâ€™s not often you get a true sequel. Itâ€™s more common in hip-hop (see eg. Jay-Zâ€™s In My Lifetime vols. 1-3 & The Blueprint 1-3), but if a rock band is going to release multiple albumsâ€™ worth of material under one title, it usually comes in the form of a double-album: classics of the genre include The Beatlesâ€™ The Beatles (1968), Fleetwood Macâ€™s Tusk (1979), and Nine Inch Nailsâ€™ The Fragile (1999).

There are confusing outliers, such as Smashing Pumpkinsâ€™ insistence on giving certain releases a subtitle or volume number, which series potentially never to be added to. Guns n Rosesâ€™ threw a curveball in 1991 with the tandem releases of Use Your Illusion volumes I & II â€”Â essentially a double album, though you had to purchase both halves separately. All of which gave rise to conflicted feelings for me, when Metric announced that their 2022 masterpiece Formentera would get a direct continuation.

One cause for concern was the extent to which the situation seemed to echo Biffy Clyro having released A Celebration of Endings (14th for me in 2020), and then finding they had another albumâ€™s worth of material almost immediately. The Myth of the Happily Ever After (2021) was enjoyable enough, but did not place for me. Perhaps a more optimistic allegory would be Radioheadâ€™s unfairly maligned Amnesiac (2001), certainly lesser than its immediate precursor, Kid A (2000), but a wonderful record in its own right. Was that a reasonable expectation?

You will recall, of course, that Formentera was my favourite album of last year, and at twelve monthsâ€™ remove, I remain happy with that assessment. My end-of-2023 Apple Music rundown informs me that I have played no artist more frequently in this year than Metric, and itâ€™s not exactly what might be considered close. The band also performed my favourite live show of the year: a couple of hours of synth-rock bliss at Camdenâ€™s Roundhouse, back in February.

Formentera II itself very much continues the pandemic angst and desire for escapism that characterised the original record. Highlights include the ultra-catchy â€˜Days of Oblivionâ€™, the semi-autobiographical â€˜Who Would You Be For Meâ€™, and the teasing â€˜Suckersâ€™, which threatens to break out of itself at any moment. â€˜Descendantsâ€™ feels like a closer, echoing some of the sentiments of epic Formentera opener â€˜Doomscrollerâ€™, before actual closer â€˜Go Ahead and Cryâ€™ heralds the (false?) dawn of a new day, as we collectively awake from the fugue that Metric have so masterfully chronicled.

Happily, I neednâ€™t have worried when Metric stood back from the near flawless Formentera, and asked â€œwant to see us do it again?â€ Lesson learned: the answer to that question, from this band, should always be yes.

1. Olivia Rodrigo â€”Â GUTS

When it comes to record releases, itâ€™s not often you get a true sequel. When last we heard from Olivia, she was heartbroken and frustrated in the aftermath of a relationship gone â€”Â pun intended â€”Â SOUR (2021). Two years later, Rodrigoâ€™s latest dispatch is another hymn book full of remarkable pop-rock gems, this time squarely aimed at the trials and tribulations of young adulthood. The heat and glare of the spotlight on someone in her position is almost unfathomably oppressive to the average person, and yet Rodrigo not only handles it with grace, she finds the words to elucidate her situation in a manner that renders it relatable. Too quickly pigeonholed as a pop phenomenon, Olivia is a wildly underrated lyricist. Opener â€˜all-american bitchâ€™ is (like many of her songs) a bombastic, ultra-self-aware jam â€”Â in this case on the precarity and impossibility of modern womanhood. Taken alongside tracks like â€˜making the bedâ€™ and closer â€˜teenage dreamâ€™, the listener bears witness to a supremely talented songwriter wrestling with expectation, fame, and the ephemerality of youth.

All of that sounds quite heavy, which is misleading, because GUTS is also home to the same infectious, effervescent joie de vivre that characterised SOUR. There was no more self-effacingly goofy song this year than â€˜ballad of a homeschooled girlâ€™, unless it was â€˜love is embarrassingâ€™. And then thereâ€™s lead single (and my favourite song of 2023), â€˜vampireâ€™: a masterclass in song construction that fits the highs and lows of a riveting emotional journey into little more than three minutes.

I hit GUTS so hard when it released in September, that I had to force myself into taking a break. As a substitute, I found myself regularly playing Cyndi Lauperâ€™s Sheâ€™s So Unusual (1983), a now 40 year old pop landmark that carries its message across four decades as clearly as a bell. Thatâ€™s the company in which I place Olivia Rodrigo, even at this early point in her career. I hope sheâ€™s around for decades to come, explaining the world and the heart through the medium of perfect pop music.

â Return to the index of lists

Ross â†’ Counsell

Nov 7, 2023

I saw the news last night (GMT) and my jaw dropped. I don’t think I’m alone; perhaps the most widespread reaction to the news that the Chicago Cubs have fired manager David Ross, and signed Craig Counsell, is shock. And it’s not because Counsell isn’t a great manager â€”Â the argument can be (and has been) made, that he’s the best in MLB. He’s certainly in that conversation. What makes the move so stunning is that, at the end of the 2023 regular season, there was absolutely no talk that Ross’s job was at risk. A hero of the Cubs' 2016 World Series team, universally beloved in the clubhouse, his managerial career had got off to a rocky start when the pandemic decimated the 2020 and 2021 seasons. Then, a league-wide lockout rendered Spring Training a mess, and delayed the start of the 2022 season. Arguably, 2023 was the only ‘normal’ season of Ross’s career at the helm, and when the Cubs fell frustratingly, agonisingly short of the playoffs, most voices agreed that it was a poor finish to a season that showed promise for a new core group of players.

Plus, Cubs' President of Baseball Operations, Jed Hoyer, had made no indications that a managerial change was on his mind. “I was very pleased with Rossy this year,” he told reporters at the end of the season. â€œRossy had a great season, and the players play hard for him. Heâ€™s our guy.â€

So, what changed? Quite possibly it’s as simple as: Craig Counsell became available. All other things being equal, I think the Cubs go into the 2024 season with David Ross. But when arguably the sport’s best manager hits the market, I guess you have to have that conversation â€”Â and apparently you have to have it in absolute secrecy, so that when the news lands, it hits like a brick.

There are other considerations. Perhaps the move is an argument that the Cubs see the position of Manager as more important than other teams. Maybe,Â as The Score ponders:

the managerial role is one of the great remaining market inefficiencies in a game where seemingly every underpriced skill or trait has been unearthed in the 20 years since “Moneyball” was published

Or perhaps it means that The Cubs are going all in on 2024. Even before the news of the new manager sent seismic waves through the National League, things were shifting for the Cubs. Marcus Stroman and Cody Bellinger have both hit free agency; Assistant General Manager Craig Breslow left for the Red Sox; strategy coach Craig Driver and bullpen coach Chris Young have both been let go. What the Counsell appointment means for the rest of the coaching staff remains to be seen1 We’ll also have to wait to see what other moves the front office make over winter. The hunt for an every-day first baseman continues, and there’s the mouthwatering prospect of the bidding war for Shohei Ohtani, whose next contract will almost certainly break all records.

There is some core continuity for next season, with newly minted Gold Glove winners Ian Happ, Dansby Swanson, and Nico Hoerner all returning (alongside lineup regulars like Seiya Suzuki, and others). Yan Gomes will be back behind the plate, and the option on (now only remaining player from the 2016 squad) Kyle Hendricks has also been picked up. But there’s no denying that this change in leadership is a huge, shocking move. It’ll take me a while to get used to seeing Craig Counsell on the top step of the Cubs' dugout.

  1. Personally, I’m hopeful that pitching coach Tommy Hottovy will remain with the team. ↩︎

The Last Black Man in San Francisco dir. Joe Talbot (2019)

Nov 6, 2023

On first watch â€” and I anticipate several â€” this, for me, was a film about belonging: to whom do things belong, and to where and to whom do people belong? What stories do we tell ourselves, and tell one another, about the places, groups, categories, and boxes in which we belong?

There are more finely-grained layers here â€” including a politics of place so specific, that I presume it lies beyond the full grasp of even other Californians â€” but the film succeeds so wildly on the human level as to welcome every viewer who has felt the pang of these questions.

Match that up with a visual sensibility thatâ€™s always finding new ways to capture the essence of a city (without reaching for gimmicks), a poetic screenplay with a real heartbeat, and a pair of strong, invested central performancesâ€¦ this felt like something special.

Me half an hour into the film: â€œWhoa, is that Daewon Song!?â€

Me towards the end of the film: â€œHey, thatâ€™s Thora Birch!â€

Me watching the end credits: â€œWait, that was Jello Biafra?â€

The opening hours of Alan Wake II have touches from so many things I love: the original game â€” of course â€” but also Control, House of Leaves, a little Max Payne, and more than a pinch of The Matrix Resurrections. One component of the gameplay is also a little like Twin Peaks meets Phoenix Wright, which is not a combination I knew I wanted until now.

If you’d like to follow along with the trip, I’ve reactivated my Instagram & Threads accounts â€” I anticipate I’ll be posting there fairly frequently: a bunch of Stories, a bushel of notes.

Since I’ll also be using a Japanese SIM, I’m cautious of relying on services linked to my usual phone number. So, if you need to reach me for any reason, the best options will be via email, or Instagram DM. Say hi ğŸ‘‹ğŸ»

Oct 28, 2023

The short opinion piece from Maine-resident Stephen King, in the NY Times today, has an air of resignation about it.

When rapid-fire guns are difficult to get, things improve, but I see no such improvement in the future. Americans love guns, and appear willing to pay the price in blood.

For some reason the piece doesnâ€™t point to it, but King published an essay on the same subject a decade ago, following the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

Lost in Translation dir. Sofia Coppola (2003)

Oct 28, 2023

On this date, 20 years ago, Sofia Coppolaâ€™s Lost in Translation (2003) had its UK premiere, at the BFI London Film Festival.

Iâ€™ve adored the film since I first saw it, and I’m excited to wrap myself in a blanket this evening and revisit it for the first time in a few years. Hey â€”Â as it’s now eligible, perhaps at some point I’ll discuss it at length for an episode of Flux Observer.

As readers of this blog may know, right now I’m a couple of weeks out from visiting Tokyo for the first time. Lost in Translation is one of the pieces of media that has done the most to colour my idea of the city for the last two decades. Whilst I’m cognisant of the fact that it’s written and shot from a particular vantage point, I’m expecting to have a moment or two, when I’m there, in which I’m reminded of the film.

If you have the time and inclination, there are few double-bills better than Lost in Translation & Spike Jonzeâ€™s Her (2013). They were released almost exactly a decade apart.1 The two films are written & directed by former spouses, and each of them won the Oscar for Best Original Screenplay. Plus, of course, both have Scarlett Johansson.

  1. Her debuted at the New York Film Festival, 12 Oct 2013. ↩︎

Crimes of the Future & Infinity Pool

Oct 25, 2023

One night this week, my special lady friend was otherwise occupied, which meant I got to indulge in a filmic treat for spooky season. She’s not a horror fan, but it’s one of those genres where I can have a good time with almost anything: from your A24-produced ‘elevated’ piece, right down to your ridiculous, schlocky gore-fest with a terrible script. I also find that ‘horror’ is a broad church. On the one hand you’ve got movies shot as though lights weren’t in the budget, relying on jump-scares and tense scores. On the other hand, there are more ruminative films that set out to unsettle and disturb in different ways. The two flicks I sat down to were decidedly of the latter camp: a double-bill of the latest offerings from the Cronenbergs, father & son.

Crimes of the Future (2022) dir. David Cronenberg

Rarely has a film more aptly fit the descriptor ‘unsettling’. Taking place in a future where pain is eradicated and humans have begun to mutate, the particulars of this story’s high-concept sci-fi are less interesting than the nuances it draws out of its cast. Frequent Cronenberg collaborator Viggo Mortensen croaks, groans, twitches, and constantly clears his throat as he embodies (literally) some mix of artist and art object. Kristen Stewart dials in a weird, but perfectly calibrated performance as a researcher who is at once infatuated, awestruck, nervous, and coy.

As with several entries in this strain of the director’s work, there’s a lot of (fairly gross) body horror stuff going on, and I was struck by how much better it works with practical effects than in those few cases where digital work is employed. The furniture in the home of Saul Tenser (Mortensen) is one example: a bed with fleshy limbs to turn him as he sleeps, and a chair seemingly formed of bones, which shakes and jostles him as he attempts to eat. Their functions remain unexplained, but Cronenberg returns a few times to the discomfiting sight of Mortensen in one or the other’s weird embrace.

As hard a film as it is to describe, it’s equally hard to recommend to anyone who was not already likely to seek out new material from this director. For anyone who’s on the fence, maybe start with The Fly (1986) or eXistenZ (1999), and know there’s more where that came from.

PS. Cronenberg used the same title for a short feature in 1970. I haven’t seen it, but the synopsis sounds truly crazy.

Infinity Pool (2023) dir. Brandon Cronenberg

In comparison to his father’s film, Brandon Cronenberg’s latest is a little easier to sit with. But that’s an unusually high bar, and Infinity Pool is still a somewhat confounding piece of work. If I remember the trailer correctly, it doesn’t reveal the film’s actual central premise. I’m all in favour of that kind of obfuscation, and so I’m not about to spoil anything here. I will say that the film feels like a natural, and welcome, evolution from Brandon’s previous feature, Possessor (2020), and tonally reminded me of elements of Nocturnal Animals (2016) crossed with Plan B & Punchdrunk’s 2020 TV event The Third Day.

Alexander SkarsgÃ¥rd gets to play a range between swaggering narcissist and terrified captive, and Mia Goth inhabits a new flavour of deranged weirdo with every bit of the screen presence she brought to roles in X & Pearl last year. How successful the film ultimately feels to you is going to hinge on how well you take to the premise, once it’s revealed.

Priya Ragu â€”Â Santhosam

Iâ€™m also a big fan of Julyâ€™s film work. It kind of breaks my brain that Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005) is creeping up on two decades old, and 2020â€™s Kajillionaire is an absolute gem that I need to rewatch soon.

Also, if you have Â£3,500 you donâ€™t know how to use, you could pick up one of 25 extant copies of this â€˜book sculptureâ€™: Services July made in 2020.1

Bonus: July’s also in the video for the new Sleater-Kinney single ‘Hell’.

  1. but you have to let me visit and read it ↩︎

Oct 16, 2023

Friends, I’m still only half here, but I wanted to mention a couple of things I’ve put out recently.

â€¢Â Last week, after an unplanned hiatus of almost exactly a year, I sent a new issue of my occasional newsletter miscellany: Tendrils. You can browse a complete archive, and sign up for future issues, right over here.

â€¢ This week, after a break of ~7 months, I released a new episode of my film & music nostalgia podcast: Flux Observer. You can find a full archive, and links to the show in your podcast app of choice, right over here.

My setup for both of these uses no cookies, no trackers, no adverts, and no analytics. As such, I have no idea how many people are reading or listening, but that’s absolutely fine with me. If you spend some time with one or the other, and want to get in touch, you can always drop me a line!

Oct 11, 2023

Lately, instead of chain-listening to world affairs podcasts, I’ve spent a bit of time catching up with 2023 music releases that aren’t eligible for the end-of-year list. Some highlights:

Celeste: Lately

I don’t really understand what’s going on with this release. Celeste appears to have put out a 5-track EP in 2019, titled Lately, and another in April of this year, with the same title. The 2023 version has three of the same tracks (in a different order), a pair of tracks from the superb 2021 album Not Your Muse, and a newer track: ‘To Love a Man’, which was released as a single in 2022.

Format weirdness aside, there’s not a weak song here, and her voice remains rich and captivating. I’ll take another album just as soon as it’s ready.

Masca: Sink

A 6-track EP rooted in Chvrches-esque synth-pop, but with added guitar in the mix, and a wider tonal gamut. I can’t seem to find much on the band, but what’s here is certainly interesting enough that I’ll keep an ear out for whatever comes next. The song ‘Animal’ feels like something of a misstep, but the two tracks that follow more than make up for it. Title track (?) / closer, ‘Sink Sink’ is going into rotation for a while.

DARKSIDE: Live at Spiral House

Second live album from NicolÃ¡s Jaar’s DARKSIDE project. I’ve been really into the two studio albums released under this name, even if my favourite recent Jaar release remains 2012-2017, the 2018 LP he put out as Against All Logic. This live set imbues the sound with a real sense of space, and a bit of looseness.

Cole Pulice: ‘If I Don’t See You in the Future, I’ll See You in the Pasture’

I enjoyed Pulice’s album Scry towards the end of last year. This is listed as an EP, but it’s a single track. Music like this feels like an antidote to atrophied attention; if you can be present with this song for 22 minutes, it’ll take you somewhere.

Kode9 / Burial: ‘Infirmary’ / ‘Unknown Summer’

A split single with a split personality â€”Â if these two weren’t on the same label, the logic behind this would be questionable. But I guess when you run the label, you can do what you want. Kode9’s frenetic, choppy piece is outshone by Burial’s dreamier, adventurous second offering.

Saoirse: fabric presents Saoirse (Mixed)

I have a private Soundcloud queue where I’ll throw any mix I hear about that sounds appealing â€” it serves as perfect background / writing music a lot of the time, but every now and then something starts playing that gets me out of my chair. This is the best set I’ve heard recently.

Oct 8, 2023

The End of the 2023 Online Season ğŸ‚

Oct 1, 2023

It’s that time of year again. Today, I kicked some dry leaves on a walk into town, bought and drank my traditional one-per-annum Pumpkin Spice Latteâ„¢, and listened to Red (Taylor’s Version) with rapture.

A whole 364 days ago, I wrote what proved to be the final issue (to date) of my erstwhile newsletter. In it, I explained the reasons behind my practice of taking an extended period each year, away from the social internet. I won’t repeat all that here; it suffices to say that when the Chicago Cubs are playing baseball, you’ll find me online, and when they’re not, I aim to be far less connected. The way things have worked out, a rough month for the Cubs has seen playoff hopes evaporate, and the final game of the season is due to start in just a few hours' time. Hence, I’m publishing this note to say goodbye for a while â€” there will be less activity here between now and next spring.

Some people reading this may recall that, last time around, the whole ‘defaulting to disconnection’ thing didn’t work out as planned. Elon Musk’s acquisition of Twitter (RIP) a few weeks after I pulled the plugs, created such fascinating turmoil that I couldn’t look away. As I wrote here back in January, the earthquakes sent through the landscape of the social web felt genuinely exciting for a while. Mastodon had a moment; Bluesky threatened to have a moment, and then never really did; many others (cohost; T2 / Pebble; Nostr; Post News) made ripples of varying sizes; Meta launched Threads to great fanfare, and then set about the harder work of making it stick. All of which is beside the point to a large extent, save to say that â€” for me â€” the excitement has given way to baseline intrigue. The rise and fall of individual platforms is less interesting than the fact that things are changing. For what it’s worth, I’ve very much enjoyed continuing to share notes and updates of various types right here.

Will I continue to post throughout my offline season? Possibly. The long-heralded trip to Japan is a few weeks away, and will likely yield a good number of photos â€” some of those will probably appear here. I’ll also feel free to drop by with anything else that seems worth saying. As explained in that post from a year ago, this isn’t a monastic practice, but a shift in default. One thing is virtually certain: the end of year list of my favourite records of 2023 will be posted in the final week of the year.

For now, let me wish you a happy and cosy autumn and winter. Keep the internet warm for me, and I hope to be back here with you next spring. The Cubs play the White Sox, Friday 23 February 2024, 14:05 CST.

If you need me in the meantime, you can always write.

Sep 29, 2023

A second album of new material from Cleo Sol in as many weeks, and new Wilco, amongst the records added to the queue. ğŸµ

Sep 26, 2023

With the exception of a few key things â€”Â travel money; travel insurance; transport to the airport â€”Â it feels increasingly as though the planning for our upcoming trip to Japan is in good shape. All of the hotels are booked; SIM cards are in hand; rail passes are winging their way here as I type; I even managed to successfully navigate the byzantine complexities of booking tickets for Universal Studios.

Alongside all of the admin, there have been a couple of other strands of prep: I’ve been watching a lot of YouTube videos (of varying quality and usefulness), and taking notes as I’ve made my way through the guidebooks I posted about a while ago. Another book just got added to that stack, with the news that W. David Marx’s Ametora: How Japan Saved American Style (2015) is being reissued in a revised edition.

I’m also trying to read more Japanese fiction in the run-up. I’ve long been an admirer of some of the bigger names: I read some Banana Yoshimoto in my teens; Haruki Murakami, about whom I’ve written before (1, 2, 3); & Sayaka Murata (whose Convenience Store Woman (2016 trans. 2018) remains one of my favourite reading surprises in recent memory. In an effort to broaden those horizons somewhat, I’m currently enjoying Emi Yagiâ€™s Diary of a Void (2023) & SeichÅ Matsumotoâ€™s Tokyo Express (1958 trans. 2023).

Sep 26, 2023
Sep 23, 2023

I dont recall when, or why, I started giving my Apple devices names beginning with sibilants, but itâ€™s too late to stop now!

Sep 23, 2023

I have just archived 63% of the entries in my Contacts, keeping only the people I’ve communicated with â€” one way or another â€”Â across the last five years or so. It’s amazing how much extraneous stuff builds up in these places if you’re not paying attention: your old landlord; people you worked with for two weeks, eight years ago; window cleaners from other places you’ve lived.

And then there’s another tier, of folks you once called friends, but one or other of you moved on from a job, or a city. There’s a tinge of sadness in archiving those names and numbers, and it’s partially attributable to how historically poor I am at keeping in touch with people. Honestly, it’s bordering on a failure to grasp object permanence! People who still regularly talk with their old school friends, and former colleagues, put me to shame.

When it comes to physical clutter, I try my hardest to resist the ‘Monica’s closet’ approach; I’m pretty good at letting that stuff go. When it comes to digital clutter though, I see little harm in keeping it around past its immediate usefulness, as long as it’s all organised in some way. I have a partitioned external hard drive dedicated to timestamped backups and archives of this kind: a whole lot of 1s & 0s, not cluttering up the place day-to-day, but retrievable if it should become necessary. You never know when someone might ask for a window cleaner recommendation.

The final begins this evening at 19:00 (GMT +1), and it’s the match-up I predicted: Magnus Carlsen vs Hikaru Nakamura. It should be fun, and you can watch via the link above, on Twitch, or on YouTube. â™Ÿï¸

Sep 15, 2023

For the record, I don’t listen to all that much metal. I used to â€”Â for around a decade, starting in the mid 90s, it was one of the staples of my listening diet. My most music-obsessed friend still enjoys a lot of the stuff, and suggestion from him is how most of the metal crops up on these lists. I’m always happy to dip into any record once, and every now and again, I still find something that ignites a spark. Sep 14, 2023

I’m currently deep in the planning stages for a trip to Japan in a couple of months' time. Flights and hotels are all booked, and SIM cards have been acquired. I’ve done my research on things like public transport and the necessity of having both cash and a Suica card in your pocket at all times. I’ve figured out which Japan Rail Pass option works best (given that we’re going to be using it both directions between Tokyo and Kyoto, as well as down to Osaka), I just need to pre-order it for collection.

Honestly, the most confusing aspect of the whole trip so far has been coming to grips with the overly-complex method for securing entry to Super Nintendo World!1

The most recent research I’ve been conducting is on architecturally significant buildings, and I wanted to take a second to note the extent to which KenzÅ Tange’s design for St. Mary’s Cathedral in Sekiguchi (constructed 1963-4), resembles a PlayStation 5.2

  1. If you think buying an entry ticket for Universal Studios Japan will guarantee that you get into SNW â€” let alone get on any rides â€” you are a but an innocent naÃ¯f. ↩︎

  2. Or rather, I suppose I should say, how much a PS5 resembles the Cathedral. ↩︎

Sep 13, 2023

A note of follow-up to yesterday’s post: the Apple event went pretty much as expected. They got that brief Apple Vision Pro segment in at the top, and unveiled some neat evolutions to both Apple Watch and iPhone. The former arguably got the bigger bump, with the new phones a more modest update. Nevertheless, I saw what I needed to regarding the camera specifically: the jump from the 12MP on my iPhone 12, to the 48MP on an iPhone 15 (with double the optical zoom) is substantial.1

Aside from the new hardware, I applaud the company’s discontinuation of leather products. This was framed as part of a comprehensive environmental sustainability project, but also has significant animal welfare implications.

  1. I was also impressed by the demo of 24MP images at double resolution. ↩︎

Sep 12, 2023

It’s that time again: Apple Event day, and this is an upgrade year for me. More by circumstance than design, I tend to pick up every third iPhone. And, whilst the performance of my iPhone 12 is still perfectly good, the battery has certainly started to degrade. What’s more, I’m currently in the middle of planning a trip to Japan this autumn, and I’ll want to have the best camera possible in my pocket. I’m excited to tune in a little later and learn what’s on offer; my expectation is that â€”Â beyond the switch to USB-C, and the debut of Dynamic Island on non-Pro models â€”Â the hardware will be a relatively modest update.

Beyond the new iPhones, and the expected new Apple Watch model, I’m wondering whether any time will be devoted to Apple Vision Pro. Even if it’s limited to a short segment showcasing a different use case, I’d expect that Apple will want to remind the world that the product exists, and is shipping relatively soon.

On the software side: there’s plenty in iOS 17, iPadOS 17, watchOS 10, & macOS Sonoma that I’m keen to play with1. I’ve held off on installing any of the public betas, so it’ll all be new to me when the full releases drop.

  1. not least of which: I intend to barrage people with an overabundance of iMessage stickers ↩︎

Sep 10, 2023

Another set of visual inspo bookmarks, as I’ve shared before. Previously, I was cataloguing these in a service called Savee, which is still a good source, but I don’t recommend the tool: significant elements of their Pro plan simply do not work, and their customer service was lacking. I did some looking around at alternatives (eg. Dropmark, which I used many years ago; Are.na, which seems popular), but I’ve now taken to scrapbooking them in Freeform, which is proving to be ideal for just this sort of thing.

I think I’ll continue to showcase a selection here from time-to-time though.

Sep 10, 2023

This conversation between Olivia Rodrigo & Phoebe Bridgers was fun â€”Â including the part where they start talking about Beau is Afraid:

RODRIGO: I watched that new Ari Aster movie Beau Is Afraid and I got so scared. I literally had to walk out of the theater. I have never had such a visceral reaction to a movie in my life. It felt like a bad acid trip.

BRIDGERS: [Laughs] I’m so glad you brought that up, because you are right. That is the scariest movie I’ve ever seen, but I was laughing the entire time.

RODRIGO: That’s the only reasonable reaction. Your body just can’t process it. You have to laugh.

I recently bought Beau is Afraid. When I saw it back in May, it was one of the most intense moviegoing experiences I’ve ever had, and I’m fascinated to return and pick apart why (particularly, but not exclusively) the opening act worked on me so profoundly. I can see it slotting in next to Aronofsky’s mother!, Nicolas Winding Refn’s The Neon Demon, and Julia Ducournau’s Titane as another film I love, but can put myself through only very infrequently! ğŸ¿

Sep 10, 2023

Yesterday afternoon, I was walking into town to meet up with my sister for the first time in months, and to see a movie. About 300m from my front door I rolled my ankle hard in a pothole â€” and I mean, I heard that sucker go as I collapsed.

The last time I broke a bone was c. 1991, and for a moment there I thought that run was over. This morning, Iâ€™m 85% convinced itâ€™s just a bad sprain.

Mostly Iâ€™m posting this to commemorate the death of my 2023 Apple Fitness activity ring closure streak. RIP

Sep 8, 2023

Good morning. It’s not every week that a former list-topper releases a new album, so I’m excited to see what Olivia Rodrigo has for us on her sophomore record. Plenty of other intriguing propositions also, including Romy’s solo debut. ğŸµ

Sep 7, 2023

I’d seen this piece â€”Â Business Insider: ‘Social Media is Dead’ â€”Â doing the rounds recently. Essentially, it argues that there’s a move underway from broadcast-style social media, towards smaller, closed-group socialising. Since the main feed has become a place for celebrities, influencers, and brands, it has come to feel less and less like a place for regular people to post:

Culture in general has kept a lot of people from showing up because they don’t think their life is aesthetic, or they don’t think that they’re selling anything, so why would they post on social media?

This rings true. The aspect that’s less-discussed is the extent to which the ‘new’, less open mode of social sharing is still taking place on some of the same apps:

There’s this sublayer of Instagram that’s much more true to what the app once was, but it is just not viewable to the general public.

Hence, the decline in public posting from regular users means very little to the companies who own the platforms, because ‘while sharing has tailed off, consuming content hasn’t slowed’. Meta doesn’t really care how much or how little you post, as long as your engagement time stays high. Whether or not you publish your own content, if you’re still seeing others', you’re still seeing adverts.

The existential threat to these platforms comes when folks get what they want from their smaller, closed groups, and decide on a media diet that doesn’t include corporations and famous people. The mental leap away from viewing mainstream social media as ‘social’, and towards viewing it as ‘media’ is a useful one. If the main feed isn’t a place to share anymore, it’s just another source of entertainment, interspersed with a lot of adverts.

Sep 7, 2023

Iâ€™m crossing my fingers for Jockstrap to take home the Mercury Prize this evening. Iâ€™m not convinced that, in the modern listening landscape, these awards amount to much â€”Â better to (accidentally or otherwise) make something that becomes a TikTok meme â€”Â but itâ€™d be nice to see them recognised for making a genuinely exceptional record in I Love You Jennifer B.1

At a glance, my other favourites from the shortlist are Olivia Dean, and Young Fathers. Coverage of the prize ceremony will be live on BBC Four from 21:00 (GMT+1) & BBC Radio 6 Music starting a little earlier at 19:00. ğŸµ

Sep 6, 2023

Last night I went to see Passages (2023), a beautifully-shot love triangle tragedy set in Paris. The mechanism of the film is essentially the central character making a series of selfish, ego-driven decisions (or, more accurately, acting on his own desires without much consideration). Those around him â€”Â and principally those with whom he’s romantically involved â€” are seen struggling with the profound repercussions. As the third act arrives, you’re desperate for other characters to finally draw a line, and call him out. Judging from overheard conversation during the credits, some people in the audience struggled with the protagonist’s lack of development. It’s certainly frustrating, but I found it to be an accurate portrayal of narcissism: people like Tomas (Franz Rogowski) rarely change, and certainly not overnight. The point in the film at which his claims to have done so are disbelieved, brings genuine catharsis.

Ben Whishaw is subtle and tender as Tomas’s husband, and AdÃ¨le Exarchopoulos is characteristically soulful. These two are the film’s principal loci of empathy, your admiration and sympathy increasing as you become evermore infuriated by Tomas.

Looking for something a little less emotionally fraught, I came home and streamed CÃ©line Devaux’s feature debut, Tout le monde aime Jeanne (2022) â€” a light, mature romantic comedy that also touches on loss and depression. The most obviously unique touch is the insertion of kinetic and characterful hand-drawn illustrations (also by Devaux), which certainly make the eponymous protagonist’s anxious internal monologue more palatable. I was also taken by the choice to saturate the whole film with bold, rich colour. It somehow served to ground the characters in a vibrant, safe-seeming world, even whilst they struggle. As Laurent Lafitte’s Jean says at one point, â€˜anxiety is more difficult in beautiful settingsâ€™. ğŸ¿

Sep 5, 2023

Last night I was present to watch Chris Farren demolish the hottest, sweatiest room in Oxford. The set list, heavy on (excellent) latest album Doom Singer, was raucous and played at 110% volume. Adorned with some humour and vibrant projections, at heart this was the purest rock spectacle available in the city on a Monday night. If you’re not already a fan, there’s a good chance the video for ‘Cosmic Leash’ will convert you. ğŸµ

Aug 24, 2023

On last week’s episode of The Vergecast, host Nilay Patel requested that listeners send photos of their childhood computer rooms. A photo of me from c. 1992 sprang to mind, so I sent it in. I did not, however, expect to get brutally roasted in the caption.

Aside from the weird sartorial decisions, there are a couple of elements of this photo that I like. I’m playing Sonic the Hedgehog, which I think puts this somewhere between Christmas 1992 â€” when I got my Mega Drive â€”Â and summer 1993, when we moved out of this house. I remember a good number of the Atari ST games in that box of floppy discs. It’s fitting that Lemmings is at the front though, because that was my mum’s one and only gaming obsession until Candy Crush some three decades later. I also like the oversized game boxes on the shelf above, which would have held a couple of floppies and an instruction manual, but bigger meant more shelf space. In particular I remember loving that Simpsons game that is right in front of me. And finally, as if this photo wasn’t 90s enough, check out the pair of phone books!

A decade’s worth of world-building and storytelling, and it looks to be coming to a close in quite spectacular fashion. I was also glad to hear â€”Â during today’s Destiny 2 Showcase event â€”Â that there’s a structure in place to continue the game on, beyond this final large-scale expansion.

If you also play Destiny, search for me in game as zioibi#6738 â€”Â let’s gather some tithes together! ğŸ•¹ï¸

Meteorite Chess

Aug 21, 2023

If chess isn’t your thing (yet), you would be forgiven for thinking that chess is chess. But even for games played by the normal rules of chess, thereâ€™s a huge variety of time controls that have dramatic impacts on play. You can, of course, play without any time limit, free to leave days between moves if you wish. Games at the FIDE World Cup â€” which is in its final stages at the moment â€”Â are played with 90 minutes on each playerâ€™s clock for the first 40 moves, and an additional 30 minutes added after move 40. Also, 30 seconds are added per move. This is a version of the classical chess format, which has endured throughout the gameâ€™s long history. But other time controls have gained popularity, perhaps particularly since the advent of online chess. There is Rapid chess, where players might start with anything from 60 minutes to 10 minutes on the clock; Blitz, where clocks start with five or even three minutes, and sometimes two seconds might be added per move; and Bullet, where games can start with as little as 30 seconds on the clock!

But those are just the chess formats that use the normal rules. There are also numerous variations that tweak the way the game itself is played. For example, there is Chess960, wherein the order of pieces on each playerâ€™s home rank is randomised; Crazyhouse, in which pieces you capture can be redeployed on your side; and 4 Player Chess, in whichâ€¦ there are four players, and four sets of pieces on one (larger) board. And thatâ€™s just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to chess variants.1

There has also been an explosion in the number and variety of chess video games, many of which feature fun spins on the game. See, as just two examples, Shotgun King: The Final Checkmate, and Zach Gageâ€™s Really Bad Chess.

I mention all of this because I recently had an idea for a new variation, which Iâ€™m calling Meteorite Chess. The game uses the usual setup of chess pieces, and proceeds as a normal game of chess. The twist is that at set intervals (ie. every three or five moves) one square on the board becomes highlighted, and after the subsequent moves, that square is hit by a meteorite. I can see there being two versions of the game: Meteorite & Meteorite Oblivion. In the latter version, when the meteorite hits the highlighted square, any piece on that square is destroyed, and removed from the board. This is the simpler version of the game, but it still requires both players to adapt their play to accommodate squares which become temporarily hazardous. The game design trick would be in making sure that the squares were selected in a fair way. For example, no squares on the 1, 2, 7, or 8 ranks should probably be targeted at the beginning of the game. Perhaps they become eligible to be meteor struck after 30 moves, incentivising players to develop their pieces earlier. The fun of the game would be to embrace its randomness, but there could also be tweaks to guard against the feeling of unfairness â€”Â eg. a setting to provide two movesâ€™ worth of warning before a meteor strikes.

In the non-Oblivion version of the game, things get a little trickier, and perhaps a little more interesting. Here, instead of destroying the piece on the targeted square, the meteorite devolves it to a lesser piece. So, a struck queen becomes a rook; a rook becomes a knight or bishop; a bishop becomes a pawn; and a struck pawn is destroyed. In the majority of instances, this would still prove an incentive for players to avoid the targeted square, but it would give rise to fascinating board states where it might prove beneficial for a player to deliberately move a rook onto the highlighted square, because devolving it into a knight would provide a positional advantage! Again, there are options here to tweak the rules to make things more or less punishing: perhaps a setting that includes some devolving meteorites, and some that outright destroy, as well as the option to either indicate which type of meteorite is coming, or not. Heck, maybe there could even be evolving meteorites, which would increase struck pieces: knight to rook; rook to Queen etc.

As Iâ€™ve said here before, Iâ€™m not a game designer. But if anyone reading this would like to make use of this idea, feel free! â™Ÿï¸

  1. If Crazyhouse sounds like fun to you, take a look at Bughouse! ↩︎

Aug 14, 2023

Seeing this piece about the NY Times prohibiting use of its content to train AI large language models, reminds me to share that OpenAI (the company behind ChatGPT etc.) recently documented a method for excluding the content of sites you own / control from their crawlers and scrapers. You could argue that this is something they should have done prior to scraping most of the open web to feed their LLM, but there’s no reason not to implement it now. Simply add the following to your site’s robots.txt file:

User-agent: ChatGPT-User
Disallow: /
User-agent: GPTBot
Disallow: /

Reason 151 to publish to a site that you control.

Aug 14, 2023

Last nightâ€™s loss to the Blue Jays had me wondering something: why does it feel like the 2023 Cubs rarely manage to close out a series sweep, and why does it feel like they always falter on Sunday?

I quickly tallied it up. So far this season, the Cubs have played 20 regular season games on a Sunday, and won five of them: a winning percentage of .250

Their winning percentage for the season as a whole currently stands at .517 â€”Â more than double! What is it about Sundays? âš¾ï¸

Aug 14, 2023

My thanks to Chris Brandrick for sharing this article â€”Â ‘The Ultimate-Rare story: 40 years of brilliant British games’ â€” in this week’s issue of his newsletter: Switch Weekly. Somehow, it had entirely escaped my attention that Rare was an evolution of Ultimate!

Jetpac was one of my absolute childhood favourites for the ZX Spectrum, and I have fond memories of Donkey Kong Country exploding my mind at Christmas in 1994. How did I not know they were made by the same people? So many of Rare’s titles have brought me joy over the years, including (but not limited to) Killer Instinct, GoldenEye 007, Diddy Kong Racing, Perfect Dark, & Viva PiÃ±ata. After reading this piece, I’m tempted to check out the Rare Replay compilation of 30 games, which they released for the company’s 30th anniversary. I’ve just noticed it includes Jetpac!

Aug 13, 2023

Nice to see that Jason Heyward’s recent success in LA has warranted a piece in the NY Times. He was one of my favourite players to watch, particularly in the early years of his contract with the Cubs, and it’s a delight to see him having a season worth noting. The article starts with an unnecessarily pointed dig at Heyward’s former club:

he can still help a team, which is more than the Chicago Cubs seemed to think when they decided to cut ties with him last August

But, as the piece goes on, it does lay out the case for his having been let go:

When Heywardâ€™s O.P.S. dropped to career lows in consecutive seasons â€” .627 in 2021 and .556 in 2022 â€” it was evident that his time there was done.

Indeed, that’s kind of the point of the piece: Heyward’s 2023 season to date has been an unexpected upswing:

Heywardâ€™s on-base plus slugging percentage (.797) is his highest over a full season since 2015. He has produced the best isolated power (.216), home run percentage (4.2 percent) and walk rate (11.5 percent) of his career.

Not mentioned are the struggles that have been experienced by Heyward’s replacement in Chicago: Seiya Suzuki, whose workload has recently been reduced to give him space to work on his plate approach. There was, however, one piece that stung: Heyward’s admission that â€œThe toughest thing for me was not trying to win every dayâ€. The Cubs' post-World Series decline, and quick collapse into a rebuild, are much discussed. It pained me a little to hear that Heyward shared fans' impatience with the front office’s strategy. âš¾ï¸

Aug 13, 2023

Today I sent the final newsletter issue of this summer’s Sipped Ink read-along, bringing to a close six weeks of enjoying Barbara Kingsolver’s fantastic novel Demon Copperhead (2022). As always with this project, I come away from it feeling both energised by the community â€”Â it’s great to have carved out a discrete space to discuss books â€”Â and a little drained. I was better about my own schedule this year than I have been in the past, when it was too common that the weekend arrived with me still having all the reading to do, let alone the note-taking and newsletter writing. For the most part I stayed on top of it this year, having been better about taking notes during the week, which were easier to flesh out on the weekends.

It helped that the novel was so good. I don’t do any kind of organised reader feedback, but my instinct is that the best of these read-alongs have been when the book is eminently readable. That might sound obvious, but it’s actually counter to the spirit in which I started the whole enterprise. Don’t get me wrong, it’s understandable that participants feel the most engaged with the easier-to-read titles (The Goldfinch, Great Circle, & Demon Copperhead amongst them), but I initially started the read-along as an accountability mechanism to push me through longer, more challenging works (Infinite Jest, 2666). This shouldn’t be mistaken for a complaint â€”Â I also very much enjoy reading these more popular books â€”Â but it makes me wonder what the reception would be amongst current participants if I was to move back towards longer or more complex novels.

Now that the read-along is done, I’m flush with the giddy freedom of being able to choose to read whatever I want! There’s a new Stephen King on the horizon, but that’s three weeks away. Before then, I’m hoping to pick up a couple from my ‘Want To Read’ stack. ğŸ“š

Aug 9, 2023

A pair of highlighted passages from recommended recent newsletters:

our political and social structures, the philosophies and ways weâ€™ve educated ourselves arenâ€™t up to the task of truly, ethically handling many of our contemporary technologies or sciences of the quantum echelon

Craig Mod: Roden #082 â€”Â ‘Sandwiches, Oppenheimer, Shooting Film’

As much as A.I. has gotten better at making human-like art, creation is arguably the easiest step in the process of cultural formation. Every day thousands if not millions of people propose new ideas and practices, but only a tiny sliver ever win attention, attract adherents, or take on collective meanings. Ironically, generative A.I. has emerged just as we’re already emeshed in a human-created crisis of cultural overproduction. Most human-created art today fails to take on social value.

W. David Marx: Culture: An Owner’s Manual â€”Â ‘Our Natural Human Defenses Against A.I. Culture’

Aug 9, 2023

I’ve just finished Barbara Kingsolver’s superb novel Demon Copperhead (2022), winner of both the Pulitzer Prize and the Women’s Prize for Fiction (and yet, curiously not nominated for the Booker Prize). The book was my pick for this summer’s instalment of my annual read-along project, Sipped Ink, and as such, most of what I have to say about it has made its way into the weekly newsletters over the last six weeks. I will say that it’s absolutely proven to be one of those novels that I’m simultaneously sad to finish and glad to have read. Heartbreaking, deeply empathetic, and told in the voice of one the most endearing narrators I’ve encountered in a long while. ğŸ“š

In fiction, he creates them; he serves himself sleet, hail, sun in the eye, all for the chance to play through them.

Aug 2, 2023

Another Wes Anderson note for the day, since I just watched The Afterparty s2e4. Say what you will about the specifics of Anderson’s filmmaking style, but imagine having crafted a bespoke look and tone unique enough to be parodied. Other episodes of The Afterparty have co-opted the styles of whole eras (regency period), and genres (romcom; noir; heist), but s4e2 is borrowing solely from Anderson. How many other filmmakers could you do this for and expect wide recognition from the audience of a half hour comedy? Hitchcock? Miyazaki? Tarantino maybe? Even then, I think it would read to many as a broader adoption of the genres in which they operate. ğŸ¿ğŸ“º

Aug 2, 2023

Ever since I saw Asteroid City a few weeks ago, I’ve been pondering a re-watch of Wes Anderson’s whole back catalogue. Reading this piece by Khoi Vinh has suggested a new frame through which to do so:

Anderson is a child at heart, of course, and that shows up countless times in his films, whether itâ€™s in his scripts or his stage dressing or his picture book-like cinematography. However, the flip side of this youthful empathy is that Anderson is essentially lost when it comes to adult characters and, by extension, stories about adults. For me, this is the weakness that sabotages films like The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou and the abysmal The Darjeeling Limited, which are populated with nonsensical, schematized characters that talk at one another but never truly interact.

My personal ranking of Anderson’s movies, as it stands right now, looks like this:

1 â€” The Royal Tenenbaums
2 â€” Asteroid City
3 â€” The Grand Budapest Hotel
4 â€” The French Dispatch
5 â€” Rushmore
6 â€” Moonrise Kingdom
7 â€” Isle of Dogs
8 â€” Fantastic Mr. Fox
9 â€” The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou
10 â€” The Darjeeling Limited
11 â€” Bottle Rocket

I’m not sure I’d call The Darjeeling Limited ‘abysmal’ as Vinh does, but it’s one of a few that I’ve only seen once. I recall coming away from it very disappointed, and I don’t recall now what it was about the film that didn’t work for me. I find it interesting that Vinh offers a reason for the relative weakness of both Darjeeling & Life Aquatic that I’d not considered before â€” it might be fun to go back through Anderson’s oeuvre with this in mind. (FWIW Bottle Rocket is another I’ve seen only once, and which felt to me like Anderson’s Pablo Honey: by no means bad, but containing only glimpses of future greatness.) ğŸ¿
