Sahotaâ€™s way with detail and allusion is enough to convey some aspects of his narratorâ€™s plight, but heâ€™s unwilling to give over much narrative space to exploring the depths of addictionâ€™s misery. For a writer of Sahotaâ€™s talents, this is clearly a choice about the type of novel he wants to write. I couldnâ€™t help but feel some disappointment, however, at the focus being placed on a relatively predictable romance plot instead of something more substantive.

Ultimately I found China Room to be very readable; Sahotaâ€™s style is characterised by an easy flow, with a particular talent for enlivening scenes through the description of details such as facial expression and clothing. I found both of the narratives, separately, were enjoyable despite the reservations outlined above1. I remained less convinced, however, that the novel does much to draw out an interesting parallel between the two. There is the familial relationship, and the shared geographic location of the two plots. But, beyond that, there is only the broadest of generalities. In an interview with The Guardian around the novelâ€™s release, Sahota attempts at first to make the case for a deeper connection between the bookâ€™s two narratives:

â€œThe two strands of the novel talk to each other,â€ he says. â€œThereâ€™s this mutual haunting thatâ€™s going along â€“ the echoes and the mirrorings and the whispers across time.â€

However, I found the manner in which he goes on to characterise this relationship to be telling:

â€œBoth characters are seeking a kind of liberation, and theyâ€™re both suffering.â€

This, of course, could be said of virtually any protagonist in any novel. It is the very basis of storytelling that a character wants something, and suffers in trying to obtain it. In China Room, the mere fact that the two characters are blood relatives did not feel like enough to establish meaningful parallels between their individual struggles.

I came away from China Room having enjoyed the novel, though lamenting its slightness. Of course, it would have been a very different book if the stories of four generations had been included, and it is understandably not the novel that Sahota has set out to write. Nevertheless, choices such as the inclusion of the nascent Indian revolutionary movement as a plot element in Meharâ€™s story, left me wanting to know more of what happened to the family between the times of the two included narratives. I couldnâ€™t escape the feeling that a vital part of the wider story had been elided, and that each half of the novel as it stands suffers from the absence. This, in turn, contributed to an overall sense that Sahota had elected to include parts of two narratives, as opposed to a satisfyingly deep exploration of either one. China Room could very well be the opening volume in a captivating family saga; I would return to its settings and characters, and to Sahotaâ€™s sure-handed depiction of them, with pleasure. As it stands however, I found China Room enjoyable, but somewhat wanting for depth.

  1. Indeed, my main complaint is that I wanted more detail, and more depth from each. ↩︎

Mary Lawson â€” A Town Called Solace (2021)

Aug 28, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

Without having planned it this way, I seem to have begun reading the 2021 Booker Prize longlist by alternating philosophical novels with those more story-centric. A Town Called Solace falls firmly into the latter category, and as such Iâ€™m going to make an effort to leave story specifics to the end of these notes, so as not to spoil things for interested future readers.

One of the great strengths of A Town Called Solace is the interplay between its three narrators. The manner in which Mary Lawson portions out plot beats to the reader is well judged. Often one characterâ€™s narrative will tease a further revelation to which another of the narratorâ€™s holds the missing piece. Even if the narrators themselves arenâ€™t able to put all of the puzzle together, the reader feels increasingly rewarded by the plotâ€™s breadcrumb trail. I enjoyed the interplay between the three narratorsâ€™ blind spots, and how it placed the reader at the centre of a Venn diagram: the only one who got to see a full picture. Occasionally Lawson cannot help but use this device with good-natured cruelty, closing Chapter 7 with a dramatic event, and immediately switching (in Chapter 8) to the vantage point of the one character who isnâ€™t involved. This, however, only served to keep me turning pages, and I found it to be an excellent method of constructing a thriller.

Alas, technique â€” and Lawsonâ€™s perfectly serviceable, unexceptional writing style â€” didnâ€™t prove to be enough to sustain the novel for me. Having completed it, my overall impression was that the author was more interested in place than plot. Her love for the particular region of Canada in which the novel is set, is evident even before she opens the â€˜Acknowledgementsâ€™ section thus:

The town of Solace exists only in my imagination, but the setting is very real: the vast and beautiful area of lakes and rocks and forests known as the Canadian Shield, in Northern Ontario. Locating the story there was an act of self-indulgence on my part; it is the landscape I think of when I think of home, and writing about it allows me to revisit it in my mind. (p289)

It is a shame then, that Lawson doesnâ€™t do enough to make the reader fall in love with her setting or her characters. When I think of Fannie Flaggâ€™s southern US, or the Maine of many Stephen King novels, I have a far more vivid mental picture of the locales, and a better sense for the texture of the culture: the way the language is spoken, customs, and mannerisms. Those authors are both excellent at conjuring personality (of both persons and places) from detail, in a way that Lawson has not mastered. Even the narrators, with whom we necessarily spend the most time, remain less than fully realised up to the close of the novel.

Before writing in more specific detail about the plot, Iâ€™ll close the non-spoiler portion of these notes by saying that A Town Called Solace is the weakest of the four longlisted novels Iâ€™ve read thus far. Itâ€™s certainly not unenjoyable, but I came away feeling as though it had not fulfilled the potential of its setup, instead settling for sentimentality.

OK, if youâ€™re still reading this Iâ€™m going to assume youâ€™ve either read the novel yourself or have no intention of doing so. If the former, I wonder whether you share my frustration with its denouement. Perhaps it is my failing as a reader, but to my mind a novel that sets as its inciting incident the disappearance of a young girl, should have in store some revelation about that mystery. In A Town Called Solace, Roseâ€™s disappearance is treated as central to the plot, until itâ€™s resolved in a cursory couple of paragraphs and thereafter has no bearing on the rest of the novel. I found this case of Chekhovâ€™s missing girl to be deeply unsatisfying in a story sense. I had anticipated that upon Roseâ€™s return she would provide a key missing piece to the mechanics of the plot, but instead it turns out that the author has merely kept her off the page as a way to animate strains of the narrative involving Clara and Liam. Rose, introduced as strong and wilful (at least through her sisterâ€™s eyes), is given no agency or voice, and the details of what happened to her are treated as entirely unimportant once her return has provided some form of resolution for Clara.

Similarly, I did not like the manner in which Liamâ€™s story closes. It is possible, in showing his (and Joâ€™s) vacillations, that Lawson is attempting to construct a version of the running-to-the-airport scene that might end a romantic comedy. However, itâ€™s a â€˜romanceâ€™ introduced so late in the novel that there is no possible way a reader can feel any investment in it. Lawson lays out Joâ€™s backstory (including a needlessly cruel relationship history) in a short paragraph less than 20 pages before the close of the novel, as though just then realising that the character remains little more than a sketch. Likewise the third act arrival, and swift departure, of Fiona felt like a hollow attempt at showing the emotional progress Liam had made during his time in the wholesome, healing environs of Solace.

That Lawson chooses to end the novel with the first meeting between Liam and Moses (the cat with whom he has been sharing a house for months, but has never seen), speaks directly to the bookâ€™s sentimentality. Iâ€™m certainly not averse to that tone in principle, but in order for it to work the reader must feel invested in the world of the novel: its setting, and most importantly its characters. I didnâ€™t feel as though A Town Called Solace did nearly enough to make that possible. Whatâ€™s more, given how little it makes of the mystery at its centre, the book has little else to fall back on.

Anuk Arudpragasam â€” A Passage North (2021)

Aug 21, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

One of the joys of choosing to read the entirety of the 2021 Booker Prize longlist, is being able to start novels knowing very little about them. I began Anuk Arudpragasamâ€™s A Passage North without so much as having read the back cover, and I was delighted to find a novel full of heart and human feeling, unafraid to address the largest of topics with an assured, light touch.

I was most impressed by the structure of Arudpragasamâ€™s novel, which has at its centre a relatively simple narrative: someone associated with the protagonistâ€™s family dies, and he travels to attend their funeral. From here, however, the author uses the spine of the story to make a series of discursive forays into larger questions in Krishanâ€™s life, and on his mind. The manner in which the text moves smoothly into and out of these extended meditations is handled with the utmost care. The reader finds themselves caught up in Krishanâ€™s thoughts on a particular poem, or his hopes and fears surrounding his relationship with a partner,Â and is then returned to the slow-moving flow of the main narrative with something more about Krishanâ€™s character having been illuminated. These discursionsÂ â€”Â which hold a prominence in the text above that of the contemporary action, such that in truth they are the substance of the novel â€” are sometimes intensely personal, and sometimes more widely scoped. As such, it will help the reader to have at least a broad understanding of the contours of the Sri Lankan civil war, but tellingly the more universally accessible themes are the more specific, interpersonal ones. I found particularly affecting the saga, relayed early in the novel, of Krishanâ€™s grandmotherâ€™s declining health, and thus declining independence. Arudpragasam makes of it a delicate, compassionate examination of pride and human frailty.1

For the majority of the text, an overall arc to the novel remained hidden to me. However, towards the bookâ€™s conclusion I found Arudpragasam introducing a suggestion of personal growth for Krishan. In earlier periods described in the text he sometimes exhibits a tendency to conceive of his own experience as being, in some respects, qualitatively different to those of other people

It was as though for most of his life heâ€™d been driven by a longing that was somehow stronger or more insistent than that of most people he knew, by a desire that had to meet more resistance than average before it could be vanquished

Towards the culmination of the narrative, however, his experiences at Raniâ€™s funeral seem to have widened and softened Krishanâ€™s thinking. He begins to comprehend something of the universality of the human experience, not just intellectually but on a deeper, more personal level. Arudpragasam has carefully introduced these ideas throughout the novel â€” as part, for example, of Krishanâ€™s retelling of the story of the Buddha â€” but only towards the textâ€™s conclusion does his protagonist begin to exhibit a deeper-seated, personal understanding of them.

This nascent insight, of course, cannot extinguish the baseline suffering of the human condition â€” what, in Tamil, would be called à®¤à¯à®•à¯à®•à®®à¯ (thukkam), and which western Buddhists are more likely to know by its Pali name: dukkha. Towards the very end of the text we find Krishan attempting to establish for himself a frame for this dilemma that places â€˜desireâ€™ in contrast to â€˜yearningâ€™:

To desire, in a sense, was to know or think one knew what one wanted, to know or think one knew the paths by which it might be reached, even if those paths turned out to be too difficult to follow, even if the things they led to, the things one desired, turned out not to provide the liberation one thought. To yearn on the other hand was to be lost, to lack bearings in the world because one did not know what one was seeking or where it could be found, so that unable to distract oneself, by frenetic activity or single-minded pursuit, from the painful sense of lack, oneâ€™s only consolation was to look out across vast distances, as if surely somewhere in the expansiveness of the horizon, across space and sea and sky, some possibility was contained that could make life self-sufficient and devoid of need, some possibility that could bring an end to time. That such a possibility didnâ€™t exist he was now old enough to knowâ€¦

This is useful in so far as it helps him toward an understanding of both the uniqueness and the universality of human suffering. It does not, however, offer him any reprieve. We do not witness Krishan return at this point to the tension between attachment and detachment that Arudpragasam has introduced elsewhere in the novel. Regardless, we feel that he has begun to develop a greater sense of compassion, and that in itself is a profound step.

Within a story rooted in the wider Tamil struggle against persecution, Arudpragasam offers the reader a picture of several lives burdened with unique struggles. By expertly revealing the universality of suffering within the human experience, he is able to offer a different vantage point from which to view struggle at any scale. That he is able to do all of this within the form of an immensely readable, warm, and very human novel, is a testament to his great talent as a novelist.

  1. It warrants mentioning that I think I found the character of Krishanâ€™s grandmother all the more endearing because of the appearances that the authorâ€™s own grandmother makes in photos on his Instagram, such as this one, captioned â€˜first time out in two yearsâ€™ ↩︎

LuÃ­s AntÃ³nio â€” Twelve Minutes (2021)

Aug 21, 2021

During the week I played through Twelve Minutes, a video game from LuÃ­s AntÃ³nio & Annapurna Interactive, and I need to vent a little! I’ve been looking forward to this title for a while, a) because I like games that centre story; b) because I take Annapurna’s imprimatur as indicative of a level of quality; and c) because its time-loop mechanic sounded unique.

I’m more or less fighting the urge to write something longer here, because generally I don’t like to write negative pieces â€“ if I don’t enjoy something I tend to just not write about it, and move on. Twelve Minutes, however, proved to be such a disappointment on several different levels that I have to at least say something brief.

In short, this is a game with six single-screen environments1, approximately two-dozen objects with which one can interact2, and four characters, only two of whom are anything more than a plot device.

The headline actors are wasted on a script that is cumbersome and poorly thought out. The storytelling, which requires a certain density because it needs to develop in twelve minute increments, is doled out in a heavy-handed manner that elicited from me an eye-roll or groan with most of its beats. The less said about the final twist, upon which the entire thing depends, the better. Suffice to say that it makes so little sense as to undermine any affection for the characters that the player may have developed despite the rest of the game’s glaring flaws. I found myself, hours after finishing the game, shaking my head at how poorly conceived the whole thing is, and how badly it’s executed.

Worst of all, the act of playing Twelve Minutes quickly becomes repetitive and unenjoyable. Even if the player is able to parse the game’s often non-sensical logic so as to understand what they need to do next, they are required to play out the rote preceding steps for a sixth time to reach an inflection point. This includes the game compelling the player to repeatedly drug their pregnant wife into a state of unconsciousness â€“ just one of several instances of abhorrent violence upon a pregnant woman, about which the game does nothing to warn the player.

OK, I’m going to stop myself there. Twelve Minutes was first previewed in 2015, and I found it difficult to believe that the finished product some six years later was so slight, and so thoroughly disappointing in terms of both storytelling and game mechanics. At the time of writing, the game is available on Game Pass3; however, even if you’re a subscriber to that service, I can only recommend that you play it if you wish to be perplexed, disappointed, and then infuriated.

  1. And, if we’re being honest, it’s really just three small rooms and a cupboard.Â Â  ↩︎

  2. Again, fewer than ten of them are either of any importance to the game’s plot or required for the furtherance of its action. ↩︎

  3. And, honestly, thank goodness for that! If I had paid Â£20.99 for it I would be livid.Â Â  ↩︎

Maggie Shipstead â€” Great Circle (2021)

Aug 14, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize

In some ways the second book in my marathon read of the 2021 Booker Prize could not be more different from the first. Whereas Rachel Cuskâ€™s Second Place is a slim, dense novel of ideas, which confines its action to a single spread of marshland, Maggie Shipsteadâ€™s Great Circle is an epic in multiple senses of that word. Its story is rich, and is peopled with a diverse cast of characters, whose lives Shipstead weaves together into an expansive tapestry, spread over decades and continents.

I feel as though my notes here should be presented in two sections: this first, which need only be short, is directed at anyone whoâ€™s wondering whether they should read this novel. I can only say that I found Great Circle to be an unalloyed pleasure. The experience of reading it was reminiscent of first encounters with similarly ambitious novels, such as Michael Chabonâ€™s The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay (2000), and Donna Tarttâ€™s The Goldfinch (2013). Having deliberately begun the novel with no prior knowledge, I was at first surprised and delighted, and then found myself walking the emotional tightrope of being so impressed and swept along by a novel that I was desperate for it to not falter! And it does not; having spent the best part of the last two days reading Great Circle I can honestly say Iâ€™m already looking forward to revisiting it in years to come.

This is a book that is unrelentingly generous in its gifts, offering the reader countless brilliantly-orchestrated set pieces and unforgettable moments in its charactersâ€™ lives. Itâ€™s as though, having begun the novel with a sinking ocean liner, then moving to mountaintop horse-riding, and biplane flying barnstormers, Shipstead thinks why not, and proceeds to include Prohibition era gangsters, bordellos, assassination, wartime romance, and finally â€“ of course â€“Â a flight around the world. At each turn I found myself marvelling at both the novelâ€™s scope and its ambition. In lesser hands it is a recipe for either a jumbled mess or at best some camp, pulpy fun. Shipstead, however, reaches for far more, and has the talent necessary to attain it.

As an interval, hereâ€™s a small bonus since the novel inspired me to fire up Microsoft Flight Simulator. They didnâ€™t have a Steerman in the game, but this is a shot of a biplane I took out over Missoula, MT just to get a better sense of what that experience might look like.


OK, if youâ€™re still reading, be warned that the following gives some specifics for this wonderful novel that you should absolutely read.

To my mind, one of the bookâ€™s great successes is the extent to which it manages to remain interested simultaneously in both the macro and micro: the grand sweep of the narrative â€” encompassing several generations of multiple families â€” is bejewelled with many moments of crystalline beauty. Shipstead unfailingly knows when best to pause the storyâ€™s self-perpetuated momentum, and indulge in the scenes that she has brought about. Take, as just one example, this passage from the beginning of the novel that feels as though the author is pulling the camera out, better to frame the action:

Below [the shipâ€™s] lights and honeycombed cabins, below the men toiling in red heat and black dust, below her barnacled keel, a school of cod passed, a dense pack of flexing bodies in the darkness, eyes bulging wide though there was nothing to see. Below the fish: cold and pressure, empty black miles, a few strange, luminescent creatures drifting after flecks of food. Then the sandy bottom, blank except for faint trails left by hardy shrimp, blind worms, creatures who would never know such a thing as light existed. (p20)

On countless occasions, Shipstead proves herself to be enormously skilled at conjuring striking images that leaps off the page for the reader:

Once a riderless horse had run into the hangar at their aerodrome from God knows where, dreadfully burned, perhaps mistaking the structure for a barn. Theyâ€™d shot the poor thing to put it out of its misery. â€œOne time,â€ Felix said, â€œI was shooting at a German and his engine caught fire, so he climbed out onto the wing and jumped. He was wearing a huge brown fur coat and looked like a bear falling through the sky. (p89)

And, whilst I frequently found myself re-reading such moments to enjoy the frame that Shipstead had frozen, the true pleasure of the novel comes from immersing oneself in the grand, romantic architecture of its narrative. Great Circle has at its core some big questions: such as that of the individualâ€™s power to pursue their ambitions, and the extent to which ambition itself is a dangerous compass by which to navigate. I found these threads intertwined with the similarly large and thorny question of destiny in the novel, in a manner that grew pleasantly more nuanced and complicated throughout.

Early in the book allusions are made suggesting a natural order by which things progress: Marianâ€™s uncle Wallace explaining to her that â€˜Water was always on its way somewhere biggerâ€™ (p45). And, indeed, it feels like love-at-first-sight to Marian when she initially encounters flight first hand. But, as the novel progresses, there is a more troubling instance of love-at-first-sight figured in Barclayâ€™s controlling obsession with Marian.

These loves each prove to be fraught in different ways. As Barclay comes to find that â€˜what he wants is not actually in her but beyond herâ€™ (p204), so Marian â€˜longs to fly on even though the horizon will only ever recedeâ€™ (p195). The central tenet of their relationship proves to be that Marian often gets what she wants, but wonders constantly at the price; she â€˜senses she is inside a trap, the dimensions and mechanism of which remain concealedâ€™ (p187).

The relationship remains compelling precisely because Shipstead resists the temptation to make Barclay out as a cartoon villain, and is content to complicate the dynamics, and leave the complications unresolved. When the trade of sex in return for flying â€˜over the lineâ€™ happens, it is not clear to the reader whose idea it ultimately is, Marianâ€™s or Barclayâ€™s.

When, later in the text, Hadley critiques Carol Redwoodâ€™s book for trying to make Marian into too much of a romantic character, it helped emphasise for me the extent to which, throughout Great Circle, Shipstead walks this line assuredly. She is always more interested in making Marian a fuller, more nuanced presence no matter how grand and romantic the arc of her life might appear from the macro perspective.

If I had one quibble with the novel, it is that as the narratives progresses it develops a slight problem with stakes. Switching between Marianâ€™s life-and-death exploits during the Second World War, to Hadleyâ€™s love triangle, sometimes made the latter seem ridiculous. I found myself increasingly frustrated with Hadleyâ€™s sometimes myopic narration in these passages, precisely because her problems were comparatively slight.

There is every chance, however, that this has something to do with me as a reader. There is one stretch, about two thirds of the way through the novel, where multiple chapters in a row deal first with Hadleyâ€™s complicated relationship with Alexei, then Marianâ€™s complicated relationship with Caleb, and then Jamieâ€™s complicated relationship with Sarah. Shipstead may have constructed things this way so as to invite the reader to draw comparisons, but the beats of these relationships were never as interesting to me as the larger themes of the novel. As such, the portions of the book that centred relationship intrigue for extended periods felt to me like distractions from the real narrative, to which I longed to return.

It was around this same point in the novel that I began to hope that there would prove to be more to Hadleyâ€™s story than simply a clever device, teasing the reader as to what happened to Marian. Ultimately I was pleased that Shipstead refrained from making explicit comparisons between the two women. She simply provides the raw material, and allows the reader to draw from it what they wish. I, for example, enjoyed the parallel between Marianâ€™s experience in the endless white of the Antarctic, and Hadleyâ€™s in the darkness of the glow worm cave: both women unsure whether they are still alive, or if theyâ€™ve unknowingly passed through the veil into death. In the final analysis Hadleyâ€™s story proves to be far more than a mere plot device, but the novel is very much Marianâ€™s. I can imagine that knowing this, and thus being free from second-guessing the authorâ€™s intentions as to structure, will only strengthen this already extraordinary book for me on a second reading.

Aug 13, 2021

Rachel Cusk â€” Second Place (2021)

Aug 7, 2021

Part of a series on novels nominated for the 2021 Booker Prize
NB. This post discusses the entire novel; proceed at risk of spoilers.

The first stop on my 2021 Booker Prize longlist odyssey is the latest novel from an author with whom Iâ€™m already familiar. Second Place is the first work of fiction Rachel Cusk has published since the completion of her Outline trilogy three years ago1; I read those three books â€” Outline (2014); Transit (2017); & Kudos (2018) â€” earlier this year, and the experience left me eager to explore more of her work. Itâ€™s fortunate for me then, that Second Place has garnered Cusk her second Booker nomination.

Much has been made of the statement in the â€˜Acknowledgementsâ€™ section of Second Place, that the novel â€˜owes a debt to Lorenzo in Taos, Mabel Dodge Luhanâ€™s 1932 memoir of the time D. H. Lawrence came to stay with her in Taosâ€™. Doubtless, this touchstone offers one lens through which we can view Cuskâ€™s novel, but it is perhaps most instructive merely in terms of the bookâ€™s form. Second Place (similar to Dodge Luhanâ€™s memoir) is a kind of epistolary work, presented as an extended outpouring by the narrator (M) to one Jeffers, about whom we learn little. In truth, however, I read Second Place as following not in Dodge Luhanâ€™s footsteps, but more closely in those of DH Lawrence.

In her introduction to the 2011 Vintage edition of Lawrenceâ€™s The Rainbow, Cusk quotes from a letter Lawrence wrote in 1913, in which he argues that the most vital pursuit of his age should be â€˜the establishment of a new relation, or the re-adjustment of the old one, between men and womenâ€™. This, Cusk argues, is precisely the project in which Lawrence is engaged across both The Rainbow (1915) and its sequel, Women in Love (1920). As she phrases the question:

Without the context of hearth and home, childbearing, male protection inextricable from female servitude, what will love between a man and woman be?

A century later, the same question is at the centre of Cuskâ€™s novel. Throughout the book we witness M struggle with understanding, or re-conceiving, her place in the world: what is her proper relationship to the people and structures in it, and to what extent are those relationships open to self-determination or imposed by external forces? As Cusk phrased it in a recent interview with Politics & Prose, M is troubled by the question of â€˜not being sure whether the whole of femininity was a trick that you fell forâ€™. Thus, the reader is presented with a tapestry of Mâ€™s thoughts and feelings on subjects such as the evolution of her relationship with her daughter:

True love is the product of freedom, and Iâ€™m not sure a parent and child can ever have that kind of love, unless they decide to start over again as adults. (p75)

and the promise and limitations of the creative act:

Because this is partly a story of will, and of the consequences of exerting it, you will notice, Jeffers, that everything I determined to happen happened, but not as I wanted it! This is the difference, I suppose, between an artist and an ordinary person: the artist can create outside himself the perfect replica of his own intentions. The rest of us just create a mess, or something hopelessly wooden, no matter how brilliantly we imagined it. (p22)

It is a hallmark of Cuskâ€™s narrators that they are at once highly perceptive (of both the world around them, and of their own interior worlds), and also have a mysterious access to the interior worlds of others. A different novelist may choose to reveal elements of charactersâ€™ histories, personalities, thoughts and feelings, if not by employing omniscient third-person narration then through extended sections of dialogue. Cusk largely elides these conversations, and often allows her first-person narrators an almost mystical-seeming access to the inner lives of others. This, coupled with the manner in which Cusk constructs her narratives to shift easily and seamlessly between times, places, and topics, gives her novels a dreamlike quality. The reader commonly finds themselves transported, in the space of a few pages, between several periods, places, topics, and states of mind â€“ the shifts effected frictionlessly and rendered in exquisite, flowing paragraphs.

It felt to me as though Cusk provides a greater sense of evolution in Second Place than was the case in the Outline trilogy. Towards the novelâ€™s culmination there are indications that M has made progress towards, if not resolution, at least finding a greater sense of peace in the search. Second Place is a book to which Iâ€™m likely to return; the density of its ideas and unanswered questions can sometimes feel overwhelming, but it rewards the readerâ€™s willingness to be open to them.

  1. A collection of essays, titled Coventry, was published in 2019. ↩︎

Jul 23, 2021

Rizzo v Freeman

Apr 28, 2021

Baseball is ridiculous. Sport, actually, when you think about it: ridiculous. Aren’t there better things all these super-fit men and women could be doing with their time and their gifted mastery of their own bodies? Surely. But the beautiful things human beings create are rarely useful, they are made for different reasons.

There are plenty of people on the internet this morning expressing their frustration at the Chicago Cubs' recent performance. I get it: the team has lost five straight games and hasn’t scored a single run in the last 20 innings of play; 24 games into the season they’re last in their division, and only two teams in the majors have a worse record.

But there’s still a lot of beauty in this game. Take for example the storyline that has been playing out between Cubs' first baseman, Anthony Rizzo, and his Atlanta Braves counterpart, Freddie Freeman. Drafted one year apart, both Golden Glove winners and multiple-time All Stars, their respective performances on the field have been inspiring comparison for years. What’s more, they’re both eminently likeable people who happen to be friends. So, when the former caught the latter in a rundown during a game last week, it was our good fortune that he was wearing a microphone:

Final: Braves 13, Cubs 4. pic.twitter.com/wh8N3DfSbb

— Chicago Cubs (@Cubs) April 19, 2021

That moment inspired a t-shirt, which Freeman naturally ended up wearing. And then, last night, when another game was beyond the reach of the Cubs' silent offence, manager David Ross gave his first baseman a chance to pitch to his friend. Freeman had hits in each of his four prior plate appearances in the game, including a home run in the previous inning. But his red hot bat was no match for Rizzo’sâ€¦ checks notesâ€¦ 74mph fastball. It’s worth watching the battle in full, but the joy of the moment is hard to miss.

Take a seat, FREDERICK.@ARizzo44 pic.twitter.com/ArqdIRVuM3

— Chicago Cubs (@Cubs) April 29, 2021

And yet many people seem to miss it. [1, 2, 3, 4]

For those to whom the final score is everything, it seems as though reading the box score would be as good as watching the game. If you can’t take joy from moments like these the whole enterprise of sport is completely lost on you. Despite his embarrassment at the plate, Freddie Freeman gets it:

Thatâ€™s one strikeout Iâ€™m okay with. Thatâ€™s what baseball is; thatâ€™s what sports is: itâ€™s to put smiles on peopleâ€™s faces. I was on the wrong side of it tonight, but Iâ€™m okay with it. Iâ€™m sure a lot of people got some good smiles and laughs, â€˜cause thatâ€™s what sports is about.

On c. 20 Years of Writing on the Web

Apr 15, 2021

Recently, apropos of nothing in particular, I did some thinking about how and why I got started blogging. That led to a mild shock of realisation that it had been two decades since I first created a Blogger account. In turn, that seemed like reason enough for a little reflection.

How It Started

Along one of the shorter sides of the University of Reading’s main campus green space sits a building constructed mostly from dark brown brick, with a white entrance faÃ§ade. This weirdly angular structure is the Palmer Building, and it was home to a couple of milestone moments for me during my time at the University. It was in the 400 seat Palmer Lecture Theatre that I sat watching a documentary about the Sex Pistols, whilst the rest of my Law school cohort attended a gala function. It was in the same lecture hall that I saw my first iPod in the wild, looking eagerly (perhaps even a little creepily) over another student’s shoulder as he scrolled and scrolled that mechanical wheel, changing selections on the monochrome screen. I myself, at the time, was notoriously never more than arm’s reach from my CD Walkman â€“Â one professor started calling me ‘wired for sound’ for my habit of wearing headphones around my neck during her seminars.

However, it isn’t the lecture theatre of the Palmer Building that I remember most clearly, but the room directly beneath it. On a couple of rows of tables were set out a dozen or so chunky Pentium II PCs: dull metal towers the size of a (large) briefcase, and CRT monitors as deep as they were wide. At a time when only 13% of UK homes were connected to the internet, there was something magical to me about a roomful of machines wired up to the web. And the real joy of that room was that, unlike the rest of the building, it could be accessed 24 hours a day. I was already enamoured of the internet by the time I reached University in 1999, but that was where the relationship really developed. With a magnetic keycard and an entry code I could access the web any time I wanted. And so I did. Foregoing study, socialising, and sleep, I frequently left my room in Wells Hall in the late evening and â€” with Neon Ballroom or Hybrid Theory on my headphones â€” made the 10 minute walk to the Palmer Building Computer Room. Often the number pad on which you were expected to enter an access code refused to cooperate, and you had to rely on there being someone else inside who had also chosen to spend their night with the internet, and who would answer your pleading knock.

It was in that room that I asked and was asked for my ‘a/s/l’ on the brand new MSN Messenger. It was there that I ignored all dictums against installing software, and instead lobbied my fellow late night denizens to join me in multiplayer LAN sessions of Doom II. When Yahoo! Groups launched during my second year, I spent uncountable late night hours in that room arguing the merits of various punk bands with Americans in the middle of their days, and Europeans even deeper into their nights.

It was to that room that I went on September 11th 2001, having received an SMS on my Nokia 3210 from an ex-girlfriend telling me to turn on the TV. My TV wasn’t hooked up, but I knew a place I could get all the information I needed, and where I’d be able to join countless other people asking one another just what the heck was going on.

And it was also in that room that I began writing my first blog. Hosted on Pyra Labs' Blogger (pre Google acquisition), mine was the simplest stream of posts on the music I was listening to, films I was watching, books I was reading, and games I was playing.

If you wanted to hear why Deftones' White Pony was an instant classic; observe in real-time as Mulholland Drive melted my mind; read an argument about what made Invisible Monsters a worthy follow-up to Fight Club; or lament the premature death of the Dreamcast, I had you covered. In the years since, I’ve had blogs and personal sites hosted on various platforms (Wordpress, Squarespace, Svbtle), and in truth the subject matter has remained largely unchanged! Occasionally I’ve run social accounts alongside these sites, but the blog was always there as a home for my more considered lengthier thoughts.

How It’s Going

In the year 2021 I find myself several years deep into a state of confusion about what the social web has become. As the internet has grown increasingly omnipresent and ubiquitous, the amount of content generated has grown exponentially, but â€” at least in the most heavily trafficked spaces â€” the forms of expression have become homogenised. The vast majority of published material is made to fit into one of a vanishingly small number of moulds. Likewise, platform ubiquity has led to a weird blurring of previously guarded lines: social / professional; public / private etc. The nature(s) of connections between people, groups, corporations, and institutions has undergone a series of seismic shifts facilitated by these technologies.

Nine years ago I published a post titled ‘The Social Web Got Weird'1. Re-reading it now it’s fascinating how things have further developed; not as I had expected, or predicted, that’s for sure. About three years ago I published a somewhat torturous post seeking to explain the idiosyncrasies of how I used Twitter. The short version is that I had found it necessary to contort myself into all manner of untenable postures just to feel OK about using the social web. That’s not a hole I’ve managed to entirely dig my way out of, but my thinking continues to evolve.

At present I have accounts all over the placeâ€¦ but none of them are active. Or, I guess it might be more accurate to say that they are largely ‘read-only’. Some of these tools have more than proven their utility; for example, the experience of following a baseball season without Twitter would now feel much diminished. In many other cases I feel drawn to at least be notionally present simply because of how interested I am in the internet as a phenomenon. The web is still capable of making me feel thrilled and captivated and engaged. For me, the internet’s staggering power and potential remain undimmed since those days (and nights) in the Palmer Building Computer Room. The bottom line is that the web is still a place I want to be, and I have an inkling that the blog format still holds promise for me ~20 years after I first created one.

  1. Side note: that post (not quite a decade old) contains links out to six different sources, every single one of which now returns a 404. Usually I try and fix these things when I spot them, but I quite like the irony of it in this instance â€”Â link rot is real! ↩︎

Mar 11, 2021
Mar 3, 2021
Feb 9, 2021

The List 2020

Dec 30, 2020

At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Joywave â€” Possession

Three years ago Joywave announced themselves to me, and took second place on my 2017 list, with their sophomore album Content. At the time I said that I found the band â€˜very exciting if theyâ€™re going to keep making music this inventive and urgentâ€™ and guess what? Possession is another assured, multi-faceted set of a dozen uncategorisable bops. Of the previous record I listed the genres touched upon as â€˜including, but not limited to: math rock, electronica, dance, soulâ€¦â€™ and thatâ€™s still all in the mix here though, for some reason I canâ€™t quite put my finger on the new album feels slightly more humane and less coldly electronic than its predecessor.

Opener â€˜Like a Kennedyâ€™ is, for me, one of the defining songs of the Trump / Brexit era: a vulnerable, exhausted lament that asks only for the simplest things amidst incomprehensible turmoil. â€˜F.E.A.R.â€™ twists â€˜Monster Mashâ€™ DNA into a campy downbeat stomp, whereas â€˜Funny Thing About Opinionsâ€™ is an upbeat treatise on the state of internet dialogue.

This is another record of surprising, inventive dance-pop-rock cuts that was everything I wanted from more Joywave. I would love to see these guys live when thatâ€™s possible once more, thoughâ€”with the same sense of humour apparent in their musicâ€”the bandâ€™s faux-Fox News website informs me that their touring has been postponed â€˜due to pressure from health experts and communistsâ€™.

19. Oliver Coates â€” skins n slime

On my spider-diagram of musical influences there would be a large number of lines spreading outwards from Radiohead, and Oliver Coates is the newest addition. It seems like a fitting way to encounter a classically trained cellist making something heâ€™s called (probably with tongue firmly in cheek) â€˜pastoral metalâ€™.

Itâ€™s a tough task to affix meaningful labels to what Coates is doing on skins n slime, and thatâ€™s not a bad thing. Sure, I take his allusion to metal, but thereâ€™s also drone influences Ã  la Roly Porter, and minimalist composition Ã  la William Basinski & Steve Reich (with whom Coates has previously collaborated). The result is a singular mÃ©lange of a headphone record that I found mesmerising.

18. Empress Of â€” Iâ€™m Your Empress Of

Despite this being her third record, Lorely Rodriguezâ€”as Empress Ofâ€”is a new artist to me this year. She also, drum roll, made my favourite track of the year in the form of peerless, euphoric dance banger â€˜Love is a Drugâ€™. But thatâ€™s just one of the jewels on offer here. The albumâ€™s true opener (though it follows a sweet intro) â€˜Bit of Rainâ€™ is a house-infused treat, whereas â€˜Sholdâ€™veâ€™ is a more complex, layered affair.

Only three tracks break the three-minute barrier, and the album as a whole is only a little over a half hour, content to show up, put a smile on your face, and dip out leaving you wanting more. This was a trip I took dozens of times since the recordâ€™s release back in spring, and Iâ€™ll be playing it for a while yet. Iâ€™ll also be looking out both for remixes of whatâ€™s here, and for what Rodriguez does next.

17. Phoebe Bridgers â€” Punisher

Someday, I’m gonna live
In your house up on the hill
And when your skinhead neighbor goesâ€…missing
I’llâ€…plant a gardenâ€…in the yard

Those are the first lines delivered on Punisher, and a fitting testament to the fact that no one told more compelling stories on record this year than Phoebe Bridgers. A stellar lyricist, she paints a series of vivid pictures for the listener, then uses them as the setting for raw emotional openness. Itâ€™s the same formula used by her partner in Better Oblivion Community Center: one Conor Oberst. But Bridgers is painting with softer brushes and â€“ for the most part â€“ a darker palette.

The title track is a heart-rending ballad of loneliness, â€˜Kyotoâ€™ is a more up-beat invitation to sing along (if you can match Bridgersâ€™ range), and album highlight â€˜Savior Complexâ€™ is a brilliantly judged balancing act that manages to be both delicate and devastating.

For whatever reason Better Oblivion Community Center didnâ€™t really work for me last year, but Punisher is persuasive proof that I need to go back to Bridgersâ€™ solo debut (Stranger in the Alps (2017)), and also her work with Lucy Dacus in boygenius.

Side note: Bridgersâ€™ non-album cover of Radioheadâ€™s â€˜Fake Plastic Treesâ€™ (with Arlo Parks) is outstanding.

Second side note: despite its June release I was late in coming to this album for whatever reason, and I get the distinct feeling itâ€™s not done growing on me. Ask me in 6-12 months and this may well have climbed up a fair few places.

16. Holy Fuck â€” Deleter

HF took 7th place on this list in 2016 with their previous album: Congrats. I never did do the work of going back and exploring their catalogue â€” which is something I still should do â€” but when I saw a new LP drop at the beginning of 2020 I jumped on it. This is a record that has stuck around for me all year, and which doesnâ€™t sound like anything else on this list.

HF are a band doing their own thing in their own way: bending all manner of instruments to make a supreme electronic racket with a pulse. However, the guests on Deleterâ€™s opening couple of tracks make for an interesting way of triangulating the bandâ€™s place on the musical map. The understated build and break of â€˜Luxeâ€™ features Alexis Taylor of Hot Chip, and the more forthright follow-up of a title track includes Angus Andrew of Liars. (I made an additional comparison to Battles last time, and that still stands.)

My favourite track on an inventive, restless record is â€˜Momentâ€™, with its build-and-build again dynamic and krautrock hard edge.

15. Surfer Blood â€” Carefree Theatre

The last two Surfer Blood records (1000 Palms (2015) & Snowdonia (2017)) havenâ€™t found a spot in my top 20, though I remember enjoying both of them. Happily, Carefree Theatre is very much a return to the heights of Pythons (18th in 2013), if not quite Astro Coast (6th in 2010).

The sunny Florida quartet still have a way with a simple melody, decorated with pretty harmonics, and a knack for undercutting it all with a weirdly twisted lyric or unexpected shift in the tune (eg. the way the guitar line finds an unexpected low note on â€˜Parkland (Into Silence)â€™). Iâ€™m aware that I may be being influenced by the fact they have a song referencing the director, but thereâ€™s a Lynchian twist at play here: a dive from the white picket vista to the squirming bugs in the soil. Itâ€™s the gambit Pixies perfected several decades ago, but itâ€™s nice to hear a different take on it.

I havenâ€™t done the work of going back to the third and fourth records, but I expect I would find that they were weakened relatively by virtue of Surfer Blood stretching to expand their sound. Simplicity is this bandâ€™s friend, and seems key to the bright three-minute pieces theyâ€™re capable of crafting. On this record theyâ€™re embracing it with great results, even if album closer â€˜Rose Bowlâ€™ makes for disconcerting listening at the end of 2020:

On the first day of the New Year
Morning, January first
This past year wasnâ€™t great
And I think itâ€™s getting worse

14. Biffy Clyro â€” A Celebration of Endings

Previously on this list: 9th in 2007 with Puzzle; 3rd in 2013 with Opposites and, of course, 1st in 2009 with Only Revolutions. Notable for its absence in that list is 2016â€™s Ellipsis, which I found to be uneven at best and did not get played much after the first couple of listens. For that reason I approached A Celebration of Endings with both hope and caution. I was very pleased to find that it was the former that was warranted.

â€˜North is No Southâ€™ is a statement of intent, and then it gives way to a run of four tracks (â€˜The Champâ€™ â€“ â€˜Worst Type of Best Possibleâ€™) as strong as anything the Scots have ever committed to tape. â€˜Spaceâ€™ is the kind of ballad that probably has Matt Cardle dreaming of another Christmas number 1, and then â€˜End Ofâ€™ hits you over the head with a blackjack. As was the case with the previous three Biffy albums to make this list thereâ€™s not a bad track here. There are weaker moments (â€˜The Pink Limitâ€™ doesnâ€™t totally work for me), but theyâ€™re hugely outnumbered by consistently arresting songwriting and the bandâ€™s knack for finding strange new ways to twist a riff or subvert a time signature.

Thatâ€™s true from the the bruiser of an opening track, right until â€˜Cop Syrupâ€™ plays the record out like a weird update of Nirvanaâ€™s â€˜Beeswaxâ€™ (1992).

13. The Beths â€” Jump Rope Gazers

There were so many good records two years ago that I ended up appending a â€˜next best 30â€™ list to the main top 20 â€“Â thatâ€™s how I know that The Bethsâ€™ fuzzed-up guitars and playful percussion only just missed a spot on the 2018 list for their debut Future Me Hates Me. The follow-up is a stronger record on which the New Zealand quartet have honed their formidable sense of melody to a fine point.

Iâ€™m hearing some that dog. in here, only Elizabeth Stokesâ€™s voice is warmer and lighter than Anna Waronkerâ€™s delivery often was. Moments like the vocal somersaults on opener â€˜Iâ€™m Not Getting Excitedâ€™ still thrill me on each listen.

Thereâ€™s a little dip in quality at the middle of the running order, but it picks right back up with the cheerily plaintive â€˜Donâ€™t Go Awayâ€™, before heading into album highlight â€˜Mars, The God of Warâ€™: a sub-three-minute pop rock gem and the best song I know to include the word â€˜optometryâ€™.

12. Deftones â€” Ohms

As I type this there is a newly released version of Deftonesâ€™ best record sat, as yet unheard, on my hard drive. White Pony / Black Stallion is a remaster and a set of remixes in celebration of the 20th anniversary of an album that I would still pack for a desert island.

Deftones are one of the very few bands for whom every one of their records has made my list over the years, so letâ€™s review placements:

White Pony 3rd in 2000 â˜¨
Deftones 12th in 2003;
Saturday Night Wrist 9th in 2006;
Diamond Eyes 9th in 2010;
Koi No Yokan 1st in 2012;
Gore 20th in 2016

When I looked back on the preceding decade in 2005 I also retroactively had their debut Adrenaline 1st for 1995, and the follow-up Around the Fur 3rd for 1997.

But what of the new offering? After flirtations with Bob Ezrin, Nick Raskulinecz, & Matt Hyde on their last four albums, Deftones reunite here with Terry Date: the producer on their first four albums. The result is a record that sounds every bit as brutal and sonically deep as their masterpiece. Thereâ€™s proof on every track of Ohms that this is a band still able to wrangle cacophony like no one else, threading it through with both taut wires of urgent passion and flowing ribbons of melody.

â€˜Urantiaâ€™ is a Pantera riff being absorbed into a great lost Soundgarden song; â€˜Radiant Cityâ€™ is restless water chopped up by a sea monster moving slowly in the deep. And, title track and closer â€˜Ohmsâ€™, is the best song theyâ€™ve written in two decades.

â˜¨ Iâ€™m relatively confident that if I reviewed this year now White Pony would take 2nd from Eminemâ€™s The Marshall Mathers LP and would be snapping at the heels of Radioheadâ€™s Kid A for the top spot.

11. Fiona Apple â€” Fetch the Bolt Cutters

I donâ€™t know where to begin with this record. After having listened to it dozens of times I still feel like Iâ€™m barely finding my way into it. And yet itâ€™s mesmerising and breathtaking in new ways each time I give it the attention it deserves â€“Â which is to say, when I can lie down with headphones on and do nothing else.

Appleâ€™s previous album (The Idler Wheelâ€¦) ended up 17th on my list in 2012, but only four other records on that list have lasted for me over the eight years since. Iâ€™m old friends with that album now, I know the raucous â€˜Every Single Nightâ€™ and the dizzying â€˜Hot Knifeâ€™ like old friends. But I still recall when I first encountered the album, and how it took time before confusion gave way to awe. Fiona Apple doesnâ€™t make easily digestible, parseable music. But just as years spent loving Extraordinary Machine (2005) were inadequate preparation for Idler Wheelâ€¦, eight years spent in the company of that album wasnâ€™t enough to get my brain ready for Fetch the Bolt Cutters.

Thatâ€™s two paragraphs of preamble to mask the fact that I still donâ€™t really know how to talk about this record, except to say that by the time Apple starts making dolphin noises in the last 20 seconds of opener â€˜I Want You To Love Meâ€™, youâ€™re likely either in or out. I, evidently, was in all the way: through the anthem to self belief â€˜Shameikaâ€™, the self confidence mantra â€˜Under the Tableâ€™, or the howl in the face of depression â€˜Heavy Balloonâ€™.

There is a book to be written about the instrumentation on Fetch the Bolt Cutters, the way itâ€™s layered, the way Appleâ€™s voice (often in duplicate or triplicate) weaves in and out of it, the way it seems to fly in the face of conventional time signatures to create music that keeps you guessing even on the fifteenth listen. Iâ€™m not music scholar enough to attempt anything close to the analysis this record deserves. This is the best way I can find to phrase it: nothing sounds like a Fiona Apple record, and no other Fiona Apple record sounds quite like this.

10. Four Tet â€” Sixteen Oceans

It will be no surprise to find Kieran Hebden occupying a place on this list: previous appearances include There is Love in You (17th in 2010); Pink (10th in 2012); & New Energy (7th in 2017), and I have a feeling that if I were to rewrite the 2013 list now Beautiful Rewind would make an appearance â€“Â itâ€™s certainly had more staying power for me than a number of records on that list. Heck, I still play 2003â€™s Rounds and 2005â€™s Everything Ecstatic at least a couple of times each year.

Sixteen Oceans displays the same delicate balances with which Four Tet has been playing for more than two decades: electronic / acoustic; played / sampled; digital / human. These levels shift pleasingly and subtly throughout the runtime of the record, in a manner which made it for me very much an album as opposed to a collection of disparate tracks. As I replayed it, even the four shorter interstitial pieces came to feel like necessary, brilliantly judged transitional moments.

Highlights for me are the singular pulse of â€˜Teenage Birdsongâ€™, and the glowing swell of (the otherwise admittedly slight) â€˜4T Recordingsâ€™. Arguably thereâ€™s less innovation on Sixteen Oceans than there has been on previous Four Tet albums, but I donâ€™t necessarily miss it. I still find Hebdenâ€™s work captivating, moving, and worthy of frequent revisiting.

9. Caribou â€” Suddenly

Caribou previously appeared on one of these lists when he took 11th place in 2014 with Our Love. That was a record that tapped into hazy house music vibes to great effect, and there are still notes of that in evidence on this yearâ€™s release. Overall, however, Suddenly is more wide-ranging. It borrows from all over the dance / electronica spectrum, and unifies the results by threading the patchwork through with Dan Snaithâ€™s falsetto.

Album highlight â€˜Homeâ€™ is as soulful and warm as opener â€˜Sisterâ€™ is cool and stand-offish: both are sub-three minute musical jewels. Each track here has been painstakingly constructed from a broad array of influences, such that each sounds different from one another and yet uniquely like Caribou. Itâ€™s a similar art to that practiced by (former tour mates) Radiohead: somehow you know a piece of music is theirs even when it sounds unlike anything theyâ€™ve made before. Amongst my favourite tracks on the record, â€˜Never Come Backâ€™ & â€˜Raviâ€™ are imbued with the kind of warmth that just glows through your headphones.

8. HAIM â€” Women in Music Pt. III

HAIMâ€™s last album â€” Something To Tell You â€” didnâ€™t find a spot on my 2017 list. Despite a handful of very good tracks, and no outright bad ones, it never seemed to reach anything like the heights of the debut: Days Are Gone, which was awarded 6th place back in 2013. Even on first listen it was clear to me that on Women in Music Pt. III HAIM had recaptured the magic of their debut.

The formula should be familiar now: three gifted musicians who also hold the unfair advantage of being sisters, which seems to explain why their voices harmonise so perfectly. Using those tools, and a great ear for melodic hooks, they produce a more thoroughly Californian update of Fleetwood Macâ€™s blues-infused pop-rock.

And on their third LP theyâ€™re making some of their best music. â€˜The Stepsâ€™ is forthright and foot-stomping; its younger sister â€“ album closer â€˜FUBTâ€™ â€“ is a more vulnerable lament. And HAIM are happy and able to play anywhere along that spectrum. Album highlight â€˜Donâ€™t Wannaâ€™ is both achingly sweet and vulnerable whilst its percussion and soaring chorus project a core of strength.

There are also a couple of surprises that work surprisingly well: chief amongst them â€˜3amâ€™, which sounds like it fell off a Jennifer Lopez record a couple of decades ago, and which I couldnâ€™t get enough of.

7. Georgia â€” Seeking Thrills

Only two of the dozen nominees for this yearâ€™s Mercury Music Prize also has the (no less prestigious) honour of being awarded a place in my top 20.

Seeking Thrills is one of the yearâ€™s most optimistic records; itâ€™s awash with infectious positivity. There are certainly downtempo moments, such as the coy, understated self-belief mantra â€˜Till I Own Itâ€™, but there are several tracks obviously destined to soundtrack late night and early hours on dancefloors. The chorus of â€˜Never Let You Goâ€™ is a burst of beautiful euphoria set in a polyrhythmic bed thatâ€™s urging you to dance at two different tempos at once; â€˜Feel Itâ€™ has the DNA of an MIA track, but with a dance twist; â€™24 Hoursâ€™ evolves masterfully into an effervescent gem.

The first half of the album is stronger than the latter half, but there are no weak tracks. Since its release in the second week of the year this has been an easy-listening pleasure that Iâ€™ve yet to tire of replaying.

6. Taylor Swift â€” evermore

This has been the year of disrupted plans and unforeseen twists. Thus itâ€™s fitting that I had this whole list written before Taylor Swift decided to celebrate her birthday by surprise releasing an album, with ~16 hours' notice, on 11 December. Hence, two weeksâ€™ later, here I am on Boxing Day re-writing things to give this record its rightful place.

As with her other quarantine album (Julyâ€™s folklore) this is Swift in a storytelling mode, delicately and precisely teasing out the emotional truths of any situation she turns her attention to: failed proposals on â€˜champagne problemsâ€™, imbalances of affection within relationships on â€˜tolerate itâ€™ . Sheâ€™s telling the story of her own grandmother on â€˜marjorieâ€™, and spinning a tale of murder and revenge on the HAIM-featuring â€˜No Body, No Crimeâ€™ â€“ both the most fun Swift had on record this year, and her catchiest song of 2020.

Sonically though, thereâ€™s more of a sense of exploration here than on Swiftâ€™s other 2020 release. The template of simply arranged, delicately composed folk pop that was set on folklore is pulled here into slightly different shapes. Thereâ€™s a drum machine on â€˜one story shortâ€™, and skittering beats and whooshes underneath the outro of â€˜happinessâ€™, and again throughout â€˜closureâ€™. Thereâ€™s one of the clearest nods to her country music roots since Speak Now (2010) on â€˜cowboy like meâ€™.

You can probably tell from how this entry is written that, with five entries left to go, weâ€™re not done with Taylor Swift in 2020. Iâ€™ll have more to say then.

(Also: shout out to the Detroit post-hardcore quartet Dogleg who held the 20th spot on this list before Taylor dropped a last minute bombshell, necessitating a re-write; their debut Melee is officially my twenty-first favourite LP of 2020.)

5. Hayley Williams â€” Petals for Armor

The last three Paramore records have been at four year intervals (not that Iâ€™m counting down), and theyâ€™ve reliably taken their place in the middle of my lists: 8th in 2009 for Brand New Eyes, 12th in 2013 for Paramore, and 10th in 2017 with After Laughter. As such itâ€™s a welcome surprise to find frontwoman Hayley Williams so far up this list when sheâ€™s out on her own.

Musically this solo work is less vibrantly bombastic than Paramoreâ€™s more recent output, but no less catchy or endearing. Despite deeply personal subject matter (including depression, divorce, and recovery) Williams has crafted a collection of electronic-tinged pop-rock that itâ€™s impossible not to fall for. Over the course of 15 tracks she explores some more experimental percussion and production (such as on the stuttering-then-flowing, Fiona Apple-esque â€˜Cinnamonâ€™) as well as showcasing her ear for a hook, such as on the powerful earworm â€˜Dead Horseâ€™ and the Sunday-afternoon radio ballad â€˜Pure Loveâ€™. The result is an hour of consistently arresting, energising music that draws from an impressively wide emotional range.

Few would deny that the defining characteristic of Paramore as a band is Hayley Williamsâ€™s unmistakable voice. Whisper to roar, and across a truly impressive tonal range, few rock singers can match her. Unsurprisingly that is also the strength of her first solo outing, though her consistently evolving songwriting is a close second.

4. Beach Bunny â€” Honeymoon

This record is nine tracks and 25 minutes of relentless, sunny pop-rock. Itâ€™s proof if proof was needed that throwing four kids into a rehearsal room with a couple of guitars and a drum set can still result in something life-affirming and marvellous.

Opener â€˜Promisesâ€™ is first light and bubbly, and then strident and anthemic; itâ€™s followed up with the sing-along whilst you dance-along â€˜Cuffing Seasonâ€™, then we drop a couple of gears for the raw, earnest â€˜Aprilâ€™. And weâ€™re off to the races on a giddy whirlwind tour of three-chords-and-hummable-choruses pop. By the time you reach cartwheeling closer, and album high point, â€˜Cloud 9â€™ youâ€™re ready to do it all again. Go on, treat yourself. You can find 25 minutes.

Iâ€™m a simple man, and Weezerâ€™s self-titled debut is my seventh-favourite record of all time. I needed something this bright and uncomplicated this year, and my thanks go out to this Chicago quartet for delivering it so effectively.

3. Taylor Swift â€” folklore

Last yearâ€™s number one released this record with 24 hoursâ€™ notice back in July, and it has been a staple on my headphones ever since. A very different-sounding record to 2019â€™s Lover, working (for the most part) in a more subdued register, folklore is another showcase for a phenomenal songwriting talent. There are no anthemic, danceable pop explosions here, but the more muted tone and stripped back instrumentation allow for Swiftâ€™s vocals to shine, and for her lyricism to take centre stage.

Whether itâ€™s (on â€˜The Last Great American Dynastyâ€™) telling the story of Rebekah Harkness, who used to live in the home Swift now owns, or laying out the dynamics of a love triangle over the course of three songs (â€˜Cardiganâ€™, â€˜Augustâ€™, & â€˜Bettyâ€™), Swift displays a songwriting touch as light and dextrous as the voice with which she brings those songs to life. Album highlight for me (at least at present) is Swiftâ€™s duet with Bon Iverâ€™s Justin Vernon on â€˜Exileâ€™ - a lyrically exquisite heartbreaker wherein the two voices play with and against one another perfectly.

Following the surprise release of the album, Swift also put out a combination making-of documentary / live performance on Disney+ which offered insight on how the record came to be, and how her collaboration with The Nationalâ€™s Aaron Dessner came to bear this fruit. It also serves as an interesting document of how an artist usually wrapped in layers of hype and marketing, found freedom in isolation to make something intimate. The record is a fascinating balance: it represents the furthest Swift has gone into telling othersâ€™ stories (fictional and otherwise), yet each song is imbued with deeply personal feeling.

Swiftâ€™s work in 2020 has been, frankly, stunning - as evidenced by her having performed the unprecedented feat of securing two spots in the top six places of this list. Having stepped outside of both the aesthetic trappings and sonic bombast usually expected of popâ€™s reigning queen, she has made a strong case for being recognised as a generational songwriting talent.

2. Halsey â€” Manic

When you open your third record on a song titled with your given name (â€˜Ashleyâ€™) youâ€™re making a statement: Iâ€™m here to share something; this is coming from the heart. When you close that track with a snippet of audio from Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, youâ€™re signalling an emotional register of earnest vulnerability. Carrying off that conversation over the course of 16 pop songs is a tall order, and yet Manic is an unbridled success.

Someone smarter than me could probably take the musical DNA of â€˜Forever â€¦ (is a long time)â€™ / â€˜Dominicâ€™s Interludeâ€™ / â€˜I HATE EVERYBODYâ€™, examine it under an electron microscope, and figure out why it makes me feel the same way as sections of My Chemical Romanceâ€™s The Black Parade (2006). Iâ€™m not equipped to work out the reasons, I can just tell you that it happens. The first track uses piano to effect a shift from major to minor key; the second is an organ-backed, multi-tracked, 76 second opera; the third is a series of crescendos hitting like waves on a beach. Itâ€™s a masterful seven minutes at the centre of a bewilderingly good record.

Oh, and then the second half of the record kicks off with the barnstorming pop-rock â€˜3amâ€™, and then the dimly lit, sultry â€˜Without Meâ€™, then the lost KT Tunstall track I didnâ€™t know I wanted: â€˜Finally // beautiful strangerâ€™. By the time Halsey is singing an LGBT empowerment duet with Alanis Morissette you feel itâ€™s company they should feel comfortable keeping.

Folk, pop, indie rock, R&B, Korean rap - this record includes a lot, and some reviews read that as coming at the expense of depth. For me it all works seamlessly almost without exception, making Manic read like a personal, and deeply felt record, that also happens to be a pop gem.

1. Dua Lipa â€” Future Nostalgia

Hereâ€™s the other Mercury nominee, and (I have just learned) Spotifyâ€™s most played female artist of 2020. So firmly is the 2020 pop crown sat atop Duaâ€™s head that one of her best tracks of the year isnâ€™t even on this record, itâ€™s over on Miley Cyrusâ€™s Plastic Hearts - the high point of an album that very nearly made this list.

Whilst Taylor Swift was writing folk ballads in a woodland cabin it seems Dua was channeling the attentions of the pop gods to teach a neon-soaked masterclass in funk and disco-infused bangers. This is music designed in a lab to destroy radios, dance floors, and TikTok alike. All of which would be for nothing if it wasnâ€™t, from start to finish, an unmitigated success. You cannot fail to smile, you absolutely will nod along, sing along, and feel some of these beats in your bones.

The Pitchfork review of Future Nostalgia has a good line in which they say that the album â€˜sounds like three Madonna eras at onceâ€™. As someone who has a huge amount of affection for pretty much all of Madonnaâ€™s eras (not you American Life, you can sit down) this is a recipe for success in my mind. Providing, that is, that you can walk in Madonnaâ€™s shadow â€“ not an easy thing to do. Dua comes armed with the disco beats of peak Kylie, and a faultless ear for both a groove and a beat. The result is a remarkable pop record that samples White Town on â€˜Love Againâ€™, and channels John Deacon on â€˜Break My Heartâ€™, but also sounds entirely cohesive and possessed of limitless self-confidence.

The title track, â€˜Donâ€™t Start Nowâ€™, â€˜Physicalâ€™, â€˜Hallucinateâ€™, and â€˜Break My Heartâ€™ could each be career-defining encores for a lot of artists. As it stands, I get the feeling that this is just the beginning of what Dua Lipa is capable of.

This is the second year that my list has been topped by a thoroughbred pop record, and there are more albums elsewhere on the list this year than ever before which fall in that category. What I find particularly interesting is that the great bulk of my music-listening year is taken up with records from all over the genre map. At the time of writing Iâ€™ve listened to 213 records released in 2020 at least once through. From ambient and drone to jazz and metal I found records this year that I really enjoyed. But when the chips are down and I have to pick the records that genuinely gave me the most pleasure, increasingly itâ€™s pop music that I turn to. Perhaps two years in a row is a coincidence, but even if the 2021 list doesnâ€™t end up having a pop album on top Iâ€™ll be shocked if there isnâ€™t a handful of them in the mix.
