... Will Understand

Jan 17, 2015

What was the last song you became obsessed with? Around this time last year I was playing St. Vincentâ€™s â€˜Digital Witnessâ€™ a lot, and singing it, humming it, or running parts through in my mind even when the headphones werenâ€™t in. I have a history of that: songs that hook into some recess in me and loop endlessly, happily away seemingly without much effort on my part to call them to mind. But theyâ€™re also always the songs to which I find myself returning when I launch Rdio or pick up my phone to play something.

I think last Januaryâ€™s semi-obsessive repetition of that St. Vincent track was the last time it happened for me, but right now thereâ€™s another song playing over-and-over in my mind, and which I play (usually just once, but sometimes a couple of times through) at least every other day at this point: Irma Thomasâ€™s 1964 single â€˜Anyone Who Knows What Love Is (Will Understand)â€™.

The song is a three-minute masterpiece of plaintive longing and understated resolve. The subtle echo on Thomasâ€™s voice is haunting and perfectly pitched to lend a hint of loneliness to her plight, and the instrumentation is similarly restrained: a simple piano refrain that sounds like itâ€™s coming from another room, the drumming little more than tempo kept with a brush, and a bright xylophone scale that glints over the verses like light through breeze-blown trees. The pure magic of the track, for me, is caught in one moment at the end of each of the two choruses, with the choice of how to deliver those bracketed words from the title. Every time I play the song I can hear the usual, easy line for the end of that phrase: it starts earlier than Thomas actually does and goes up on the first syllable of â€˜understandâ€™ before levelling off. Itâ€™s the line that a thousand soul and alt-soul songs choose, and keeps those two words in their parenthetical place. Instead Thomas dips subtly down on that syllable, and extends it, rising slightly, before touching the final two syllables in a soft staccato. Somehow it shifts the whole weight of the song, making it not solely another love song but also a paean for understanding - as vulnerable as it is beautiful.

In Praise of the Running Novelist

Jan 16, 2015

Iâ€™ve just finished re-reading Haruki Murakamiâ€™s What I Talk About When I Talk About Running (2008). The first time I read the book it was as a fan of Murakamiâ€™s work, and over the last couple of weeks Iâ€™ve gone back through it as someone who is in training for their first marathon. Itâ€™s an odd book: a mix of autobiography, a kind of sports reportage, a little travel writing, and a healthy dose of something akin to philosophy. Murakami isnâ€™t the kind of writer to present athletics in technicolour, super-sized with pomp and meaning; as with his fiction, heâ€™s wonderful on the details: the rituals, the toll on the body, the workings of the mind during prolonged physical activity.

I just run. I run in a void. Or maybe I should put it the other way: I run in order to acquire a void. But as you might expect, an occasional thought will slip into this void. Peopleâ€™s minds canâ€™t be a complete blank. Human beingsâ€™ emotions are not strong or consistent enough to sustain a vacuum. What I mean is, the kinds of thoughts and ideas that invade my emotions as I run remain subordinate to that void. Lacking content, they are just random thoughts that gather around that central void.

These are my favourite passages of the book, when Murakami meditates on what running has meant to him â€” what it has taught him. Murakami is a pretty strong and highly experienced runner, whereas I am currently that most dangerous of things: an advanced beginner. I have no aspirations to match the times or distances that he outlines in the book, but I do find much of Murakamiâ€™s psychological approach admirable.

When Iâ€™m criticised unjustly (from my point of view, at least), or when someone Iâ€™m sure will understand me doesnâ€™t, I go running for a little longer than usual. By running longer itâ€™s like I can physically exhaust that portion of my discontent. It also makes me realize again how weak I am, how limited my abilities are. I become aware, physically, of these low points. And one of the results of running a little father than usual is that I become that much stronger. If Iâ€™m angry, I direct that anger toward myself. If I have a frustrating experience, I use that to improve myself.

Here Murakami gets close to something I have also found, expressing it more eloquently than I could. To be engaged in something as simple as running, and yet to be confronted by this simple act with concrete proof of your limitations, is humbling. In a very concrete way you are presented with evidence of your mortality, your relative weakness, and you learn something about yourself that feels solid and true.

Writing from decades of experience as both a long-distance runner and the author of multiple lengthy novels, Murakamiâ€™s notes on concentrated effort and stamina have a ring of universality to them. As in his fiction it often seems that the simple object of his description is also being treated allegorically. This certainly makes the book worthy of re-reading, and Iâ€™m pleased to have been able to take from my second time through what I hope can be lessons, or at least aids the next time I lace up my shoes.

[Running] should add a few new elements to your inventory in understanding who you are. And as a result your view of your life, its colors and shape, should be transformed.

Birdman & Enemy

Jan 7, 2015

2015 is off to a great start filmically: in just the first four days of the year I saw a pair of really interesting character studies that are also showpieces of meticulous direction. I thought Iâ€™d put together nothing more than a couple of paragraphs of encouragement to seek out these movies, as theyâ€™re both better seen without too much in the way of preconceptions.

Birdman dir. Alejandro G. IÃ±Ã¡rritu (2014)

Iâ€™ve been a Michael Keaton fan for a long while, and the run up to this filmâ€™s release was all about the excitement of getting to see him in a leading role that he could really get his teeth into. I found director IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s Babel (2006) overlong and too ponderous, and the highly acclaimed Amores Perros (2000) remains a shameful blind spot in my recent cinema knowledge. However, the trailer for Birdman had an intriguing punk tone to it, and coupled with a really neat poster, I was alsoÂ going in interested to see how the movie would work visually.Â 

I was blown away on both counts. Keaton has perhaps never been better (though I remain a huge fan of the performances he delivers in Multiplicity (1996), Pacific Heights (1990) and, of course, Batman (1989) in particular), and IÃ±Ã¡rrituâ€™s direction (along with Emmanuel Lubezkiâ€™s DP work) is absolutely mesmerising throughout. The supposed trick here, of course, is that the whole 119 minutes appears to pass in one solid take - but the real trick is that IÃ±Ã¡rritu & Lubezki find a way to do that which doesnâ€™t feel like empty showboating, but rather a vital element of the filmâ€™s interrogation of the relationship between the sibling media of cinema & theatre.

Enemy dir. Denis Villeneuve (2013)

And then, just after having my head spun by Birdman I find that Denis Villeneuveâ€™s latest is available for rental. I really enjoyed his previous movieâ€”2013â€™s Prisonersâ€”and had been looking forward to Enemy after seeing the trailer a while back.

Again, not to give too much away: Jake Gyllenhaal here plays two charactersâ€”a shy, somewhat withdrawn teacher, and a C-list movie actorâ€”the relationship between whom is unclear. They circle each other, their orbits each affected by the other, in trajectories that complicate and darken as the film goes on. Both of Gyllenhaalâ€™s performances are really accomplished: itâ€™s genuinely impressive how heâ€™s able to distinguish the two characters through posture and gesture where a lesser actor would resort to caricature. And the film itselfâ€”its look, its feel, its odditiesâ€”has really stayed in my thoughts. Immediately that it was finished I started looking around the internet for some explication of its more opaque corners, and Iâ€™ve found myself returning in my mind to some of the really striking imagery that Villeneuve constructs. As with Birdman, Iâ€™m aching to see it again already.

If these two donâ€™t end up in the top five movies I see this year then 2015 will have been an absolutely outstanding year at the cinema. There are plenty of good reviews for each out there (eg. Little White Lies on Birdman & The Dissolve on Enemy) but if you trust me enough I fully recommend going into these as cold as possible and having your head opened up a little. Enjoy.

Jan 1, 2015

The List 2014

Dec 30, 2014

At the end of each year I make a list of the twenty albums I enjoyed the most. To be eligible, a record has to be of album length (at least ~30 mins), and contain entirely (or almost entirely) new material; live albums, cover records, and compilations are ineligible.

20. Deru â€” 1979

I was introduced to Deru via his contributions to the Outliers: Volume 1 - Iceland project, in which his minimalist electronic soundscapes provided the perfect accompaniment to long, languorous shots of Icelandâ€™s stark landscapes. Over the duration of an album the tone varies a little more, but retains a chill and a slight distance. I kept returning to this record to be present with it, simply because I like the colours it paints with and the patience with which it unfolds.

19. Kiasmos â€” Kiasmos

Billed as Ã“lafur Arnaldsâ€™s electronica side-project, Kiasmos sounds pretty much as that description would lead you to believe. Built around the basis of Arnaldsâ€™s sweeping strings and intricate, sensitive piano patterns, the augmentation provided here by synths and drum machines simply serves to lend another texture to the sound. Sometimes thereâ€™s a switch to a pace Arnalds rarely achieves in his solo work, but the majority of this record poses no surprises. Regardless, I found myself enjoying this again and again.

18. Thom Yorke â€” Tomorrowâ€™s Modern Boxes

Released by some unusual method â€” as is now the usual â€” and instantly familiar-feeling to anyone who listened to Radioheadâ€™s The King of Limbs (2011) or Atoms for Peaceâ€™s AMOK (2013), Tomorrowâ€™s Modern Boxes is nevertheless another fine set of glitchy, angsty, intricate clockworks wound up and let loose by a master craftsman and endlessly curious tinkerer. Particularly if you enjoyed the album versions of tracks from Yorkeâ€™s The Eraser (2006), before they morphed and grew slightly when Atoms for Peace came on board to play them live, youâ€™ll feel right at home with this understated collection of modest but accomplished work.

17. East India Youth â€” Total Strife Forever

A complete mystery to me upon first listen, William Doyleâ€™s set of glittering, swimming electronica eventually coalesced into something I felt I could get my hands around. Conversely, I learned the best way to do that was simply to allow it to wash over me. The titular quartet could have been released as a standalone work, but surrounding those tracks with more tonally-varied pieces really serves to bring them into relief as the spine of the album but not its flesh. Iâ€™m not a huge fan of Doyleâ€™s falsetto vocal (which creeps in a few times here and there and is underwhelming rather than wholly off-putting), but his ear for the melodic throughline to a complex miasma of sound is impressive throughout.

16. Liars â€” Mess

No two Liars albums are the same, and in the shape of Mess theyâ€™ve released perhaps their best since the career high of Drumâ€™s Not Dead (2006). Opener â€˜Mask Makerâ€™ seems like a deliberate attempt to forewarn the listener that theyâ€™re in for a rough ride, but if one can learn to lean into the swings and take the bumps thereâ€™s so much here to be infected by. The albumâ€™s best track â€˜Mess on a Missionâ€™ is perhaps the bandâ€™s best to date, not to mention the best theme tune for a non-existent, Warren Ellis-scripted, True Detective-on- amphetamines, HBO show I can imagine. Liars are talented at conjuring the sound of nightmares, and are not afraid of unleashing music that is at first seemingly incomprehensible. Learn to love it however, and youâ€™ll find a lot to love.

15. Tycho â€” Awake

I caught up with this album so, so late in the year and have a feeling that given time to blossom in my mind it may float further up this list. Quickly my favourite release on label-of-the-year contender Ghostly International, Awake is a stunning collection of sur-ambient tracks that swell and sweep along lines that quickly seem familiar and yet continue to grow in the mind with each listen. I can foresee this being a record I return to for quite a while to come; Iâ€™m already kicking myself a little for not picking it up upon release.

14. Sisyphus â€” Sisyphus

Iâ€™m not even sure how I came across this record â€” perhaps via the Son Lux connection â€” but even on first listen I was fascinated by its variety and by how singular so many of its elements felt. Opening track â€˜Calm it Downâ€™ is doubtlessly one of my tracks of 2014, and Serengetiâ€™s laid-back, self-assured flow was one of the discoveries of the year for me. The album as a whole is restlessly inventive - constantly trying on new styles, sometimes two or three within the space of a single track: soul, hip-hop, R&B, electronica - theyâ€™re all in the mix here, and the combination was consistently alluring to me. My favourite moment at the time of writing is on â€˜Booty Callâ€™: the delivery of the line â€œImâ€™a kiss you like a bubble in the brooks.â€ I donâ€™t even need to know what that actually means.

13. Aphex Twin â€” Syro

The last time Richard James put out an Aphex Twin album my interest in electronic music was very slight, but even then I knew the name and something of the reputation. Syro appeared amongst much fanfare in September, and hasnâ€™t moved far down my â€˜recently playedâ€™ list since. I used the term â€˜restlessly inventiveâ€™ above to describe Sisyphusâ€™s melange of styles, but it applies here too; I donâ€™t think any two bars of Syro are identical; things are always shifting, different elements of a track taking momentary prominence and then being subverted or switched out for some other stem. Four months hasnâ€™t scratched the surface of unlocking Syro in my mind, but thereâ€™s something special about a record that still feels ultimately unknowable after so much play.

12. Manic Street Preachers â€” Futurology

At this point in their career itâ€™s a wonder that the Manics are still able to surprise. But, whilst the vast majority of its component parts are drawn from elsewhere in their storied history, Futurology still manages to arrange the building-blocks into some wonderful new shapes. Billed as a poppier counterpart to last yearâ€™s Rewind the Film the album finds the band going straight ahead on some tracks (â€™Sex, Power, Love and Moneyâ€™, â€˜Between the Clock and the Bedâ€™) but still finding plenty of room for introspection (â€˜Walk me to the Bridgeâ€™) and edgier-sounding fare. â€˜The Next Jet to Leave Moscowâ€™ could only have been written by a band old enough to harbour regrets; their willingness to spill them and work them through like this is admirable, and to our benefit. When the sums are totalled up this is the fourth in a run of great, and very different-feeling, albums from The Manics since 2009.

11. Caribou â€” Our Love

After a while spent in its company Our Love resolves into a beautiful collection of bright, spacious electronica. I found myself returning to it as a default album for lightening an afternoon, or to run to in the evenings. Perfectly paced, meticulously crafted rhythms are brought to life by an inventive instrumental palate that kept me guessing until it crept into my head completely. Album highlight â€˜Second Chanceâ€™ takes a gamble on the kind of vocal that commonly renders tracks skippable for me, but for some indiscernible reason here makes it the song I returned to most often. Thatâ€™s just one of a thousand impeccable decisions made by Dan Snaith in his production of a record that took up root on the brighter end of my electronica spectrum and stayed firmly planted through the darker months.

10. The Acid â€” Liminal

‘Liminal’ is one of my favourite words, and one I perhaps over-used in poetry seminars. Itâ€™s also a word I apply mentally to certain albums and pieces of music. Deftonesâ€™ White Pony (2000) feels that way to me, as does OK Computer (1997) for some reason. The Acid (of whom the only member I was previously familiar with is Adam Freeland) have chosen a good title for their debut LP however: the music on Liminal emerges and grows organically, fades, shifts, and evokes powerfully its own sense of place.

â€˜Creeperâ€™ is propulsive and straining at itself to break free. â€˜Basic Instinctâ€™ is understated and makes good use of the vocal effect the recordâ€™s production relies on throughout to mask a relatively slight range. I found that with this record, perhaps because it is so successful in evoking a particular mood, I had to be in the right mood to play it - but when that mood hit there was little better than spending time inside the world it builds.

9. Nothing â€” Guilty Of Everything

The closest stylistic analogue for what Nothing are doing on their debut is shoegaze, but various elements of their sound push at and perhaps tear the edges of that envelope. Whilst tracks like â€˜Endlesslyâ€™ are firmly within the tradition of My Bloody Valentine et al, â€˜Get Wellâ€™ is too rhythmic and danceable, and â€˜Somersaultâ€™ is closer to something from Hope of the Statesâ€™ The Lost Riots (2004).

Regardless, the production of the record understands well what the bandâ€™s ambition is: to flood the listenerâ€™s head with glorious, monochrome noise so that they feel subsumed by and imbued with it.

8. Taylor McFerrin â€” Early Riser

For some reason I didnâ€™t listen to much jazz this year (Otis Brown IIIâ€™s The Thought of You perhaps the best jazz qua jazz LP I spent any significant time with), and even this is borderline. McFerrinâ€™s modus operandi is to interweave soulful, understated electronica through elements of jazz (â€˜4amâ€™, â€˜Already Thereâ€™), R&B (â€˜The Antidoteâ€™), and back into soul itself (opener, and entrant on the track-of-the-year shortlist, â€˜Postpartumâ€™). Something about the resulting mix (perhaps the way it moves seamlessly from one sound to another) really worked for me. On weekend mornings and walks into work it was a pleasure to be accompanied by this album which, in all its forms, suffuses light and good feeling.

7. Run The Jewels â€” Run The Jewels 2

Hip-hop didnâ€™t come through for me this year either. The new Common album didnâ€™t get close to the hype, the long-awaited Wu Tang Clan LP had its moments but was never going to be a classic, and the same goes for The Rootsâ€™ â€¦And Then You Shoot Your Cousin. Kanye took a year off, Jay-Z took a year off, who knows if Yasiin Bey / Mos Def is working on anything?

Anyway, all of which set the stage for something new and Run The Jewels took full advantage. El-P is a decent rapper and a flat-out great beat-maker. With this record following up 2013â€™s R.A.P. Music Killer Mike is making a play for Kanyeâ€™s crown, with a knack for twisted, quotable, clever lyrics and an incredible, relaxed flow that drives the record.

The album is obviously conceived as a whole - it wouldnâ€™t surprise me to find that El-P considered the sequencing as carefully as any individual beat. â€˜Jeapordyâ€™ comes with no warning, things build on â€˜Oh My Darling Donâ€™t Cryâ€™ and when the beat drops on â€˜Blockbuster Night Part 1â€™ I just about lose it each time. But then it goes up another level on â€˜Close Your Eyesâ€™, which also happens to feature Zach de la Rochaâ€™s best verse since he stepped out for Saul Williams in 2004.

6. The New Pornographers â€” Brill Bruisers

I was a big fan of Twin Cinema (2005) but havenâ€™t exactly flipped for the two New Pornographers records between then and now. Brill Bruisers, however, is an unqualified triumph. The opening track is bombastic and sing-along whilst also proving a great showcase for the bandâ€™s huge sound. I love the way â€˜Champions of Red Wineâ€™ shimmers and builds, and â€˜War on the East Coastâ€™ pulls a bait and switch by flipping from dirge to glam in the blink of an eye.

Carl Newman refers to Brill Bruisers as “a celebration record” and certainly it sticks to the brighter, more upbeat end of the bandâ€™s spectrum. The production is outstanding, and having several male and female vocalists allows for a dialogue and a lyrical dynamic that works here as it does for Arcade Fire. Take for example album best â€˜Born With A Soundâ€™, which could easily find a home on The Suburbs: when Amber Webber sings â€œI want you all of the timeâ€ by herself a shiver runs through me without fail.

5. Submerse â€” Slow Waves

With the majority of what I listen to these days falling somewhere on the electronica spectrum, Submerse managed to pinpoint precisely where my head is with this stuff at the moment. Lushly-produced, infinitely warm soundscapes, and wonderfully balanced instrumentation helped make this probably my most-played album of 2014.

Other plaudits headed Slow Wavesâ€™s way include best album cover of the year and best opening track in the form of the stunning â€™Letâ€™s Never Come Back Here Againâ€™. Other highlights include the alluring wash of â€˜Snorlaxâ€™ and â€˜VHS.chordsâ€™, which weaves circaâ€“8-bit videogame sound effects subtly through its ebb and flow. Iâ€™ve been struggling to pinpoint precisely what it is that Rob Orme (aka Submerse) does so well, and I think the key to this sound is the perfect balance of organic-seeming electronica: thereâ€™s nothing cold here, it all feels very much as though each of its musical capillaries is pulsing with warmth.

4. Spoon â€” They Want My Soul

The narrative around the release of this record was all too concerned with the longevity of the bandâ€™s career. As someone with â€” for better or worse â€” limited prior connection with Spoon, I was able to look at the album objectively and found it to be nothing less or more complicated than a great rock record.

Itâ€™s a cleverly sequenced album: â€˜Rent I Payâ€™ is a statement of intent to open with, â€˜Inside Outâ€™ is more ruminative, slightly poppier, and â€˜Rainy Taxiâ€™ serves to display a cutting edge. Most of these 10 tracks move between moods throughout their runtime, as though the band have too many great ideas for one album. Nothing feels forced or poorly-executed however - itâ€™s clear without knowing the back catalogue that this is a group of musicians very assured in what theyâ€™re making.

The warm, just-fuzzy-enough production is outstanding, and is tweaked masterfully to fit around each song just perfectly. Iâ€™ll be playing the title track and the bombastic, anthem to bravery â€™Let Me Be Mineâ€™ for a long while to come - as well as most of the rest of the album I should think.

3. SBTRKT â€” Wonder Where Weâ€™ll Land

Previous to this year my only knowledge of SBTRKT was via a couple of (pretty great) Radiohead remixes (of â€˜Everything In Its Right Placeâ€™ & â€˜Lotus Flowerâ€™). The path to changing that was an odd one: I picked up the single â€™NEW DORP. NEW YORKâ€™ via Ezra Koenigâ€™s Twitter, and liked but didnâ€™t love it. That was enough to get me to tune into the album via Rdio, and soon after I had purchased it and was playing a couple of tracks more-or-less daily. Thereâ€™s a great variety of styles on display over the generous 15 track running order, but I started to get even more out of the record when it clicked for me that it had been built for consumption as a whole.

â€˜The Lightâ€™ sounds like it belongs on a sexier version of Hail To The Thief; â€™Temporary Viewâ€™ â€” tinged with R&B â€” is plaintive and uplifting; â€˜Higherâ€™ features Raury delivering probably my favourite hip-hop vocal performance of the year.

For whatever reason even the outlets Iâ€™m usually fairly in sync with on music were relatively down on this record (Pitchfork: 55%; Resident Advisor: 5/10). Thatâ€™s a puzzle to me as I continue to find new reasons to love a huge, warm album in which itâ€™s a pleasure to get lost for a while.

2. St. Vincent â€” St. Vincent

I really liked Annie Clarkâ€™s 2009 album Actor, but this record quickly inspired a whole new level of devotion. That was the case right from the release of â€˜Digital Witnessâ€™ on the sixth day of the year - a track Iâ€™m still playing regularly 12 months later and have not grown the slightest bit tired of.

â€˜Birth in Reverseâ€™ is all angular guitar and too-deep grooves, â€˜Bring Me Your Lovesâ€™ makes something astounding out of the under-practiced sub-genre of lament-as-anthem. But itâ€™s â€˜Digital Witnessâ€™ that still rings the clearest for me as the albumâ€™s centrepiece: in tone and subject matter a kissing-cousin to much of Arcade Fireâ€™s Reflektor, and just as stirring to each the heart, head, and hips.

1. Death From Above 1979 â€” The Physical World

I still remember the day in 2006 when I read the post on DFA1979â€™s website in which Jesse Keller used those fateful words: â€œWe decided to stop doing the bandâ€¦â€. That was two years after having released the singularly powerful Youâ€™re A Woman, Iâ€™m A Machine and thereby shifting my whole conception of how much noise two people could make, as well as altering the topography of the post-punk landscape.

Itâ€™s been a long decade since that incredible debut, and the mere existence of this second record is something like a miracle; that it lives up to the standard of the first record is a second-order miracle; and that it also finds ways to evolve the bandâ€™s unmistakable sound without sacrificing its authenticity or its power is a kind of compound triptych miracle.

(As an aside, a neat accompaniment to the album was also released this year in the form of Eva Michonâ€™s insightful, up-close-and-personal doc Life After Death From Above 1979, which chronicles the tour cycle of the first record, the falling apart, and the reconstitution of the band.)

â€˜Right On, Frankenstein!â€™ & â€˜The Physical Worldâ€™ are my favourite tracks here, but the whole thing is pretty outstanding from start to finish. Brutal, danceable, chantable, and full of great hooks - I couldnâ€™t be happier to have DFA1979 back in the world.

Dec 8, 2014

Episode VII Trailer Analysis

Nov 29, 2014

OK, maybe you were expecting this. I know that the internet just exploded upon the release of the first teaser trailer for JJ Abramsâ€™s The Force Awakens, but Star Wars has been such a huge part of my life since childhood that I canâ€™t help but add my two penniesâ€™ worth to the flood of opinions that greeted the trailerâ€™s arrival. So here goes nothinâ€™:

For all of his playful hinting from the set in the wake of spoilers, Abramsâ€™s choice of first shot in the teaser can be read as a reminder that thereâ€™s still so much about Episode VII that we donâ€™t know. For example, hereâ€™s John Boyega, whom we knew was cast of course, but itâ€™s as though Abrams is intentionally confronting you straight off with the fact that you donâ€™t know the characterâ€™s name, whether or not heâ€™s actually a stormtrooper, why heâ€™s so panicked in the sequenceâ€¦ even whether thatâ€™s Tatooine.

Secondly, it feels like weâ€™re very deliberately being shown a man in the uniform, sans helmet, Abrams playing up the fact that this isnâ€™t a faceless clone - a subtle way to differentiate his film from the clone-filled prequel trilogy in the minds of people who have a problem with those films.

Thereâ€™s also a probe droid-esque noise in the background, whichâ€”along with Boyegaâ€™s outfitâ€”raises some very interesting questions. Remember how Luke et al destroyed the second Death Star, and Vader threw The Emperor to his death, and there were dancing Ewoks and fireworks and everyone celebrating the end of The Empire? Yeah, well so how come ~30 years later thereâ€™s still all these stormtroopers around?

Feels to me like that guy in the middle is, as Princess Leia would say, a little short for a stormtrooper. Cue wild speculation about why Boyega (5â€™9â€) is hiding out amongst the Imperial ranks, and who is pulling a blaster on whom in the kerfuffle teased here.

Wait - we missed a shot. And itâ€™s the cutest shot too.

Look at that guy! Heâ€™s like Artoo meets WallÂ·E! Itâ€™s amazing how much personality this little dude has for less than three seconds of screen time. Jalopnik has a neat tear-down on this spherical droid which includes discussion of where he might fit in the R-series, and a potential explanation for that head bobble heâ€™s got going on. Also, check out the background for what looks to be a somewhat worse-for-wear podracer engine. Again, not a sure sign weâ€™re on Tatooine, but a possible hint nonetheless.

And hereâ€™s Daisy Ridley asâ€¦ well, everyoneâ€™s calling her Kira, though thatâ€™s unconfirmed right now. Her character is also rumoured to be the daughter of Han & Leia (so long Jaina, Jacen & Anakin Solo), but again: speculation at this point. Hereâ€™s what is confirmed: sheâ€™s in a rush just like that little sphere droid (again, rumoured to belong to her); she looks scared like Boyega; those shades are probably made from a salvaged stormtrooper helmet; that speeder is cool!

And then we get to see Oscar Isaac in an X-Wing! Rebel symbols, tinted orange visors, but blue stripes down the sides and S-foils that tilt up at the ends? Also, glorious nerds have translated the Aurebesh on Isaacâ€™s vest as â€˜PULL TO INFLATEâ€™!

This is my favourite shot in the trailer: a squadron of X-Wings skimming the surface of a body of water, backgrounded by mountains - this looks like an entirely different environment to all of the action of the trailer so far. At this point itâ€™s clear that Abrams is using his year-ahead teaser trailer to hit on all of the buttons Star Wars fans want pushed. In a little over a minute here weâ€™re given shots of multiple new characters, a new droid, a couple of familiar-seeming but also new vehicles, and a glimpse at a couple of the planets weâ€™ll visit in twelve long monthsâ€™ time.

And then this:

Whoâ€™s this guy? Is this Adam Driver? Is it his voiceover weâ€™re hearing throughout (or is that Serkis? or von Sydow?)? Perhaps the only thing thatâ€™s obvious is that heâ€™s bad news before he even ignites that lightsaber, and when he does weâ€™re left to speculate about how best to reconcile that leaked concept image of the alleged Sith Inquisitor with the (now pretty legitimate) leaked image of this masked dude. Also, where is he? Looks too snowy to be the desert planet, and whilst itâ€™s possible weâ€™re in the foothills of those lakeside mountains we just glimpsed, itâ€™s equally possible weâ€™re somewhere else entirely.

So, add a villain to the list of what weâ€™re teased with and it feels like a full house. It seems like such a smart decision at this stage to focus on whatâ€™s new and keep the reveals of the returning cast members for later. (Watch the internet melt the day we see frame one of Han Solo!) Intrigue, excitement, new stormtrooper helmetsâ€¦ what more could you want?

Ohâ€¦

The longest single shot in the trailer is pre-empted by a beat of black, and then that John Williams score, the looping arc, the scream of TIE Fighters. Itâ€™s amazing how much power some symbols retain. Star Wars holds a unique place in popular culture, certain elements of its mythology seemingly so deeply ingrained that even those who have no interest in it know the names of central characters and may be able to quote a line or two. Itâ€™s perfectly plausible that people who have never seen one film from the series will still recognise the Millennium Falcon. For those of us who grew up with and love Star Wars this shot is enough to bring tears to the eyes (whilst sat alone in a Regent Street branch of Starbucks). Whoâ€™s at the controls? Whatâ€™s with that new-shaped radar dish? Are those TIEs shooting at each other? Weâ€™ll have to wait a while to find out.

Nov 14, 2014

Missed Connection

Nov 8, 2014

Adrian Tomine is probably my favourite comics writer & artist working today. I got into his work with Shortcomings (2007), and immediately went back through Summer Blonde (2002), Sleepwalk (1998) and the rawer Optic Nerve stuff (-1998). Since then Iâ€™ve picked up pretty much anything with Tomineâ€™s name on it: the 2004 scrapbook of uncollected work, the postcard set, and 2012â€™s New York Drawings - a wonderful hardback collection of the covers and pieces of artwork that Tomine has contributed to The New Yorker over more than a decade.

The cover of that book features Tomineâ€™s best-known piece: Missed Connection, which was first published as a New Yorker cover on the 8 Nov 2004 issue, ten years ago today. It depicts a man and a woman, seated on separate subway train cars, making eye contact and holding copies of the same book.

Thereâ€™s something immediately sad about the scene - the simultaneous sense of possibility and the loss thereof; the unfairness of their being powerless to change the fate of being headed in different directions. I canâ€™t help but wonder where those two are going, what the likelihood of their encountering each other again might be, just what exactly they are losing by passing by each other. Whilst Tomineâ€™s graphic novel work is full of great characterisation and well-wrought narrative, his ability to capture emotionally resonant moments in single frames is often simply astounding. Nowhere is this more elegantly done than in â€˜Missed Connectionâ€™.

Prints of the piece (along with many others) are for sale via Tomineâ€™s site, and more information on his catalogue can be found via his publisher: Drawn & Quarterly.
